reviewText:
Tropico 5 was a game I picked up after watching a few YouTubers mess around with it, and so I investigated the steam page and from there things went swish!

It has a nice quirky story, while might slightly infuriate you, is quite rewarding in the end but sadly not made out to be that much of an achievement.  The characters you'll come to either love or dislike , I however never got tired of Penulitimo's comments or Lord Oaksworth's trails.

For the most part this game made me feel like I could actually achieve something by building a settlement and attempting to set it up right and in the most efficient way possible, something that Simcity 5 couldnt really achieve, or at least not very well.
While Simcity didnt do a terrible job at creating your own settlement, there were no actual problems or issues with money or power politically at all after completing your city, effectively making your only problem at that point the efficiency and placement of buildings, or the bugs inscripted in the game itself which rendered a problem unsolveable.
Tropico 5 puts you in control of everything as the ''President For Life'', as a Roman ruler once said, for production of all goods and foods, public buildings, the army, and social and constitutional matters.  Stuff up and fail to get the support of your people, and your time as El Presidente could well be up with military coups, rebel attackers, major powers invading your island (if you get them really peeved), or an annoying combination of two of these issues, OR the simple fact the you should have cheated or cheated harder in the elections.
Simcity was lacking this redeeming feature of actually trying to hold onto power, and after a decade you were basically done in that city alone (even though the game controls said otherwise).

I am a bit disappointed with the emptyness of multiplayer rooms and hearing that it had problems early on also didnt help its reputation either.
I'm also not happy with the news of a hacker who managed to figure out that for future DLC's, money will be required for most, if not all 10 future DLC's over the next year or so.
Most of the DLC's did nothing for Simcity, and actually didn't add much for the game except visual appeal, so I hope that these DLC's either aren't useless or will be free and useful at some point.
Another complaint would be at the achievements.  Some seem too easy to get, while others might take along time to figure out and be able to complete.  Not as much of a biggie, but just something to keep in mind if DLC's factor into future achievements.

The biggest complaint I would have however would be the seemingly inefficiency the infustructure buildings get by the modern era/age, seriously, it gets pretty annoying once you hit a population of 1000 and truck offices are everywhere and arent seemingly doing a lot.  I just dont get it, if you get stuffed over by this, then you could be stuck in negative bank numbers, and mostly the only way to solve a problem in this game is to throw money at it, and without exporting goods which seem to stock up in the production buildings being delivered to the docks (because the trucks aren't working for some reason), you've basically signed your defeat, and woe to you if its near an election or popularity is taking a hit and the people want change!

If you brought Tropico 4, then its a question of if you want spend the money on this one, but from what I've seen its a great overhall of the old game which might only do a few things better (and possibly worse) than its elder.

Overall, fantastic game, I would recommend to anyone interested in town planner games or political-type strategy with building elements, as while becomes harder to manage in the future ages, is actually rewarding in the end and might teach you some lessons along the way, if not the occassional laugh at Penultimo.
This game I hope won't finish here, as the developers are capable of achieving much more and adding some more layers on this cake.
The music is pretty cool also, wouldn't mind seeing some more music tracks in the future though!

reviewText: I'm completely gutted that Tropico 5 is such a terrible game. I've been a fan of the series who followed every release back to the original Tropico, and in the week leading up to the Tropico 5 release (of which I pre-ordered a 4-pack) I replayed Tropico 2 : Pirate's Cove through for about the 30th time. Old graphics, a few annoying design flaws, but even in 2014 still a spectacularly fun game, just like Tropico 1, Tropico 3, and Tropico 4... but not Tropico 5. For the first time in the history of the Tropico series we've got a new Tropico game released that is not only not a fun game, it isn't even a Tropico game. Packed with bad design decisions, content compromises, and maddeningly simplified with console limitations/mainstream stupidity in mind, for the first time in Tropican history we've got a game that can't be fixed with patches because the base game is so incredibly, irreparably broken. Tropico 5 is a corporate game-by-committee" insult to each and every fan of both Poptop's original Tropico creation and Heinimont's mostly-faithful torch-bearing continuation of the series since then. It's a bad game

reviewText:
A nice update from the previous titles in the series, this one new graphics and mechanics to make the experience new again. The campaign itself is very enjoyable as it takes place over several ages where you begin in the colonial time and progress to new periods as the campaign progresses.

Some of the new mechanics involve the economy, as you can now select specific commodities to import and export, granting you the ability to buy low and sell high, while also allowing you to target industries you'd normally lack resources to develop. Other changes also include military buildings also producing different kings of military units (e.g., Army Bases result in 3 tanks per base), which makes military expansion more strategic compared to the previous interations.

Also with this version is the inclusion of Online Multiplayer, which unfortunately, I have not been able to participate in.


Should you buy?
-----------------------------
Very much so. This is a fun macro-oriented city builder that provides an enjoyable experience. If you are a person who is compelled to buy DLC, then I suggest waiting for sales or special editions that bundle all the DLC together.

reviewText: I have owned every Tropico game ever, and while I have had my share of gripes with all of them, I was excited when I heard about Tropico 5, and really, really, wanted to like this one, but between the complete lack of sensible military strategy and the ridiculous DLC prices for what-should-have-been-released-as-updates, I cannot recommend the game, even at 75% discount.

reviewText:
Not a bad game, but I'm voting no for two reasons:

1.) Vanillas Tropical 3 and 4 are both more substantive games. Had these not existed, this would be a thumb's up. As it stands, you'd get more for your money from either of those.

2.) The incessant DLC. Don't get me wrong; I'm not against DLC. Make money for the devs, more content for us. But, for $4 apiece, you're getting a scenario, a costume, and one building. The costumes, for the most part, suck. The scenarios are okay for a one-off (though, generally speaking, sandbox is MUCH more entertaining). The buildings usually aren't substantive enough to stand on their own.

Basically, if they bundled 2-3 of the DLCs and sold the bundles for $5, it'd be much more worthwhile.

reviewText:
Only Tropico game that I've seriously disliked in the series.

Tropico 5 fails by effectively being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ stripped-down iOS-tier ghost of it's predecessors.  Important gameplay and ui features are cut away, while the UI becomes more bloated and inefficient.  Familiar concepts that set the series apart from other city-builder sims -- like being able to customize your presidential faults and qualities, which makes the game more dynamic, gives the player a wide range of gameplay styles, additional challenges and creates greater replay value -- have been removed or cut down to a micron of thier former strength.

The new concepts that are introduced (like FoW) are inconsistent with the genre, hindering that intrinsic creative value of city building.  The islands tend to be much smaller (in both campaign and sandbox) compared to the rest of the series.  The scale of buildings tend to feel bloated and awkward with few effective placeable locations.  Many of the 'new' elements are just disappointing replacements for previous staples, like cocoa being introduced but papayas being removed.  Dammit, I loved papayas...

In addition to the cumulative restrictive effect of these changes, the game tends to play carrot-and-a-stick with what little choice you have left.  The campaign (and even sandbox mode) essentially constantly micro-manages the player, which is an unpleasant if not ironic twist on gaming.  At times this is mandatory and oppressive, others it's simply and option one can choose to ignore -- however there is no benefit to attempting to do things your own way.  The player is basically caged in and asked to perform specific meanial tricks.

The UX is terrible and easily the worst-in-series.  I honestly felt that the Tropico 2 interface was cleaner, more usable and more efficient.  The Pop up build menu, which is ugly, bulky, and poorly laid out, interferes with with your world viewport inevitably blocking whatever it is you were trying to work on.  The overall design seems to be trying to accommodate touch interfaces, which in traditional iOS fashion means that your have to sacrifice detail and control for huge UI elements.  We've lost 2 degrees of speed control in Tropico 5.  The Overlay's have been turned into the ♥♥♥♥ing ugliest rainbow wire-grid that I've ever seen -- It's almost completely unusable.  The PiP viewport becomes annoying after 30 minutes, and takes up too much screen space as a non-interactive element.

All of the ui changes leave the player with less control and a more cluttered screen.  Useful elements like faction leader notices have been removed, as well as monthly/annual reports (like starvation and deaths from poor healthcare).  Mind you the game still internally wants you to build a new church, or improve healthcare, but you will be left in the dark to guess as to what the social problems are.

3/10.  Do not buy.

reviewText:
I have played Tropico since the first. I have lost many hours in the previous games of this series. It was my all time favorite game.

I pre-ordered this one when I heard about it and was so excited. I have to say it was the hugest disappointment in all my gaming years. I tried to love it and just could not.. and this was my TROPICO!

The base game lacks content seen in earlier versions, the voices of the characters in game are annoying and not funny, the music is absolutely boring and repetitive, and the devs of this game were snarky and rude to those of us that didn't think this was the next best thing to slice bread (forgive the slang).

The game is broken with some pretty serious glitches such as trade, vechiles getting stuck, shacks everywhere even dirtying up the beautification, the battles are seriously stupid with issues added to it.

The base game is overpriced for what you get and the dlc is extremely over priced for what they give.

As a long time fan of this series and it being my favorite game of all time I would say don't buy it or wait until it is in the steam dollar bin.

Do not go by the ratings, all gamers know ratings are more lies than truth when comes to certain sites.

I would rate this game as a 1 out of ten and that is being generous.

reviewText: A great game, held back by one huge flaw.  You lose everything at each era change, so everything you have built becomes negative income.  And since all of your trade routes go away too, there is zero incentive to spend any time in any era but the final one.  During one game, I had $260,000 entering the World War era, and it was increasing.  2 years into the World War era, I was in the red, being invaded, and dealing with uprisings.  I didn't have the money to upgrade my army, and got thrashed.\n\nIn a subsequent game, I was rushing each era, and managed to get through to the modern era with little trouble.  IMHO, any game that penalizes you for playing the game isn't a good game.  Get rid of that horrible transition problem, and this would be a 9/10 game.  With it, 5/10.

reviewText:
This is a dictator simulator, where you can build and rule your own country.

If you think this game is a city-building simulator, you're wrong. This game has no bridge, rigid road builder, and lack of building types.
If you think this game is a economy-management simulator, you're probably wrong. This game has poor internal and external management options, although there is export-import thingy in the game but the game itself decides how much goods to export and import.

If you have ever played previous series, Tropico 4, you probably would think that this game is not as interesting as its predecessor.

Tropico 5 has too many DLCs that each only adds little things to the game. But this game is quite amazing, one of my favourites.

Gameplay: 8/10
Storyline: 8/10
Smoothness: 7/10 (Frame rate drops when your population reaches to around 3.000)
Graphics: 9/10
Sounds: 8/10

It's better if you buy this game during sale.

reviewText: Tropico 5 probably introduces the most new gameplay mechanics out of the franchise. It certainly is not just like 4 (which in turn was just like 3). The idea of advancing with a tech tree (of sorts) is an interesting change while a consistantly changing global environment can often catch you by suprise if you get complacent. Unlike previous Tropico games, putting all your eggs in one basket will be your undoing. I have also noticed that while in older instalments I could win ellections with ease, each election can often leave me with a nail biting victory (or twice so far defeat). So I would recommend reducing the difficulty when you first play as Tropicans in 5 will rebel almost 3 times as often as those in tropico 4 with the modifier Rebel yell on.\n\nThis Game still still retains the political satire and puns of the previous Instalments and on the odd occasion has made me laugh. It does how ever have a few flaws such as; a lack of customisation for EL presedente and his Dynasty (i feel like tropico 4 had more customisation options), the more clunky almanac (i much prefer the tropico 4 almanac) and the fact that you are only warned about a faction not being satisfied when they protest (often leaving you with little time to rectify the problem before some become rebels or you lose an election).

reviewText:
I have logged about 20 hours of gameplay so far and upgraded my rating from 3 to 4 stars. I got this on steam so I was able to download it on May 23. This is very different from the previous Tropicos. The difference between tropic 3 and tropic 4 was a few more buildings, but overall was the same game. Tropico 5 looks and feels completely different. You will find this game much harder and challenging on campaign mode but now has difficulty settings. There are many new building and upgrades as well. Multiplayer is still not up but I will update this review when this mode is working as it seems like it will be fun. I have played many hours of tropico 3 and tropico 4 so I am very familiar with the series. They released patch 1.02 on June 9th, which fixed numerous issues with both multiplayer and single player.

Pros
-Graphics are updated and is much smoother than previous tropicos.
-The trading system has been overhauled and you now have a guaranteed trade ship every six months. You now also have an additional ship that you can use to trade a certain commodity at above default rate of the computer generated trade ship. Also the ships will change every so many years and look like a ship of that time period.
-You no longer have to build a separate tourist dock. All tourist ships use the same dock as what is given to you at the start of the game.
-You can now hire a manager for each building. Each manager with have certain bonuses they bring such as better efficiency or better job quality.
-Each place where tropicans work will display what income level they will be at. For example a dock worker or a farmer will be a poor tropican, but you can increase their pay to make them well-off. The housing will tell you how it corresponds to their income level. A tenement will suit a poor worker but a house requires their income to be well-off. This also applies to the restaurants and pubs, which serve the poor tropicans whereas opera houses and casinos appeal more to the rich tropicans/tourists. This is much more detailed than previous tropicos.
-There is now a constitution that will have selections such as for the labor market-all citizens 16 and older must work, child labor, or work if you want; each with its own pros and cons.
-Many new buildings including cotton and cocoa plantations. You can now build a textile mill and use the cotton you grow to make tshirts. You can now mine uranium and coal and either sell it or use it for power plants. There is now a library which is used to research buildings and upgrades per era.
-The construction priorities feel like they work much better than previous tropicos.
-The dock now shows exactly what you are exporting and the money you will generate with each item. For example: Corn-$3000
-You can now have a population well over the 650 person cap in the previous tropicos. (I currently have a population of 800 on one island and it is not even that built up, there is even one mission where I have to have over 900 people.) The low population cap in tropic 3 and 4 really limited how much you could expand and grow your island because you would not have enough workers to fill positions for every building later in the game, especially when you threw tourists in the mix.
-Plantations now have plots of dedicated land that crops will be planted on. This is much better than previous tropicos where farmers would just plant crops in random places around the farm.
-I like that in the campaign, as you move to the next mission, you continue on the same island with everything you already built and expand upon it.

Cons
-The overlays no longer include a map of minerals, instead you have to explore the undiscovered portions of the island to find mines. You now have to pay an expedition $1000 to explore differnt parts of the island and can get expensive. Also mines are only located by hills or cliffs now. You start out only seeing about 1/10 of the island and the rest is fog. I find it kind of annoying that as you build you city and reach the edge of what you can see of the island, the fog doesn't clear. You still have to send an expedition, even its across a busy street.
-You can no longer build factories until you hit a certain era.
-When trying to place a farm, the crop condition map is not as easy to read as it the square tiles are now outlined in a green, yellow, or red border, not a full green or red square. I personally found it harder to distiguish the yellow and green conditions of the map.
-In the campaign you only have a certain number of years to rule, known as mandates, and if you cant complete the level in time you lose. More challenging though.
-You have to wait to get most of the upgrades for factories till certain eras.
-You cant set wages for all farms or mines anymore (Fixed in patch 1.02). You can only set the sames wages for specific farms or mines such as all gold mines or all corn farms.
-The game will pause and go to a loading screen when it autosaves for about 5 seconds. This is just kind of annoying when playing, I hope they can patch this issue.

Overall, this game is more fun and challenging than tropico 3 or 4 in my opinion. I bet with a few updates some of the cons I listed will make this game much more fun and enjoyable. I was use to just building up my island at my leisure and building up money to purchase better buildings but tropico 5 is not like that anymore. This version requires patience and a see what this does approach in the campaign. I really like that aspect as it has created a much higher replay value. And this is like most game downloads from amazon, it will be on steam. This has been the case for many years now so don't be shocked. (And it says DRM-steam). I will update after more gameplay.

reviewText:
Maybe it's because I was spoiled by its predecessor (which you can't help but compare it to), but I found Tropico 5 very disappointing. The first thing you notice - right off the bat - is it lacks the charm and personality of the Tropico series. While Penultimo returns as hilarious as ever, all your old friends like Reverend Esteban, El Diablo and the Mighty Chinese Dragon (who's hungry for your goods) are conspicuously absent. As such, factions and foreign powers feel like numbers on a page instead of personalities.

The campaign is way too short with way too little variety. You can grind through it (fairly effortlessly) in a few days, during which you'll get to play on four islands. That's right. FOUR islands. Two of which are basically the same. As for the running of Tropico, in pandering to the needs of the crown, the people and the powers that be, you get the feeling of being a thankless civil servant rather than being a power-mad dictator in love with his own reflection, as was the case in Tropico 4.

While the implementation of Dynasties was a great idea - in theory - it was lacking in execution. Instead of three traits, now you only get one per Dynasty member. And a grand total of about four or five costumes. Thinking about sending el Presidente to a construction site to speed things up, or a building to boost service? Think again, as the option to do so is gone.

On the positive side, it *looks* nice. But as it's a Tropico game (and not a super-realistic bro-shooter), it doesn't really need to. If anything, the mandatory DX11 requirements have screwed a lot of people out of playing it in the first place. I'll have to double check, but I could swear the background music (with a couple of exceptions) is the same re-heated soundtrack from Tropico 4. Come on, folks. There's a wealth of Calypso/Carribean/Latin music to choose from. Get a LITTLE creative!

In summary, I REALLY wanted to like this game. I really did. Tropico 4 is still one of my favourite games of all time. It's sad to see what could have been an amazing game not fully realised and ideas not fully explored. Until such time as there's adequate DLC (I have no doubt they'll churn it out piece by piece in $5 increments) to give it a little variety and scope, I can't really recommend it. Go play Tropico 4. It's still a damn good game if you want to indulge your inner megalomaniac.

P.S. As if it weren't bad enough you can't build a giant golden statue of yourself any more, you can't build ANY statues. How the hell are you supposed to feel like a tyrant if you can't remake Tropico in your likeness?

In it's current release state, I'm hard pressed to recommend this to anyone in regards to fans of the series or as a general interest to city and econ simulation et al. Without delving into past Tropicos too much, these title pretty much abolished everything decent that was good about the past games and while I wanted to strive to figure out the best way to win and be efficient in Tropico 3 and 4, I find myself logging off in frustration a lot with the fifth installment.

Don't get me wrong, there is a lot of good and a ton of potential for future DLC's (hate to think that maybe this was a focal point, but it's quickly becoming industry standard). Unfortunately, the bad and the outright annoying is so prevalent that the whole experience gets ruined pretty quickly.

reviewText:
On it's own, Tropico 5 may be a B/C rated game. It has all the basics needed, building up a tropical island and a single bizzare campaign. But it's really impossible to play this without comparing it to its immediate, and fare more affordable, predecessor. Tropico 5 adds multiplayer, does improve some design and planning apsects, but strips out much of the micromanagement, a large number of building, avatar customization, a tremendous amount of detail, and nearly all the wit.  For example, instead of the corrupt political humor oozing out of the previous Tropico games, we get an endless stream of toilet humor and bad sexual innuendo with the most annoying 'host' that Kalypso could apparently find.

The list of things missing is staggering, and it's very clear that this game was designed for a long run of DLCs just to get us back to what Tropico 4 had to begin with. The game feels, and is, a massive step backward for the franchise. Multiplayer may be a saving grace, but empire builders don't tend to like multiplayer all that much to begin with, so...

In all honesty, I do regret spending any money on this game, and it's the first time I felt that way about Tropico. Excuse me as I go back to the much superior Tropico 4.

reviewText:
EDIT 1: I managed to get a somewhat speedy reply on a few of the issues I posted about in the game's official forum. Overall I am quite satisfied with Kalypso's course of action.



Tropico 5 is a good game as far as difficulty and presentation goes.

Right off the bat I noticed that the game runs better than the previous game on the same machine I played it on. There were times when I crashed due to large invasions but for the most part, the game has function well for about 95% of the time.

The Modern Times DLC in Tropico 4 was somewhat of an introduction to the multi-era gameplay in Tropico 5. I like this as it makes the game a bit more dynamic. Prices adjust depending on the Era and available technologies, alliances, and political powers differ as well. All in all the multi-era feature is a great addition to the game.

Combat in the game seems a bit lacking. I understand that combat is not the main feature of the game but if you plan to run a totalitarian state then you'd best expect to see lots of it. On addition to that, your dynasty members play a passive role during invasions, uprisings, and rebellions (in the form of global effects or manager effects). This seems a bit strange to me especially since some of them can be Tacticians or Generals. I've also had trouble figuring out how to get the rebels to attack my Palace while maintaining a strong Military. It's not like Tropico 4 wherein I can set up an elaborate trap in certain structures or have my own avatar tip the scales of battle in an evenly (numerically) matched battle.

As of now I am 60-40 on this game. It still requires a lot of polish but at the same time, I did enjoy it enough to play it to near-completion. If there was a neutral button then I'd select it. For now, I'll wait for that polish to be applied.

reviewText: I love the Tropico series *very* much, but I just can't get excited for this one. It feels much more like a run of the mill city builder game, they changed a lot of the voice actors for the main characters, they brought back the annoying radio host idea, and a whole smattering of other poor design choices. The jokes fall flat for the most part, and a lot of control has been taken from the player, and a lot of the smaller details that used to make the series great are missing. Where that's been removed, however, needless complexity has been added. Now you need a library to research technology- yep, a tech tree. Military affairs are much more integral and like many, many other terrible city sim games, it too is bland.  You are supposed to appoint managers to your buildings- but why should I waste my time flipping through all the potential managers to try to find the one that actually fits, only to get a 10 point effectiveness boost?  And if you have a plantation colony, say, you always end up with a bunch of managers for things like tourism or landscaping or speed-cubing or whatever else. I played for a few hours and lost interest. Your island is consistent across missions, which is cool, but you'd best hope your crystal ball is accurate. One mission starts with you being invaded, so I certainly hope you thought to build multiple forts and towers. Overall, it just feels like a shadow of the 4th game in the series. The 4th game, with the modern times expansion, offers a much more entertaining, satisfying game, and you can probably grab it for a small fraction of the price.

reviewText:
A good game but feels unfinished. Population caps. No ways to reduce rebel or criminal threats.

The trading is a very good system but feels unfinished as well. Many times, the resources available on your island will not be conducive to the trade options available to you but other times, and a few times there will be amazing offers that will provide you with great boosts to your economy. You need to keep an eye out. It is a good idea but can be somewhat inconsistent. Your island will constantly ship out the materials that you need instead of keeping it on island. Some buildings, such as the cannery, are a nightmare and will bog down your entire island. Kalypso must iron out balance issues between buildings and fixing small issues such as entire islands getting bogged down because teamsters stop working.

The swiss bank account still has very few/no uses.

reviewText: I recommend this game for anyone who enjoys its style of gameplay. While there may be some glitches or features which people disagree with, I believe that they are worth overlooking simply for the enjoyment of being a dictator and having to build a country against real issues. I am not a fan of being overly critical of games, and if a game gives me the slightest bit of enjoyment, then I think it is worthwhile, and I can definitely say that this game has been enjoyable to me so far. The developers created a great game, and it is a shame that some people cannot look past small mistakes or glitches. There is a massive distinction between degrading complaint and constructive criticism.

reviewText:
A good game but feels unfinished. Population caps. No ways to reduce rebel or criminal threats.

The trading is a very good system but feels unfinished as well. Many times, the resources available on your island will not be conducive to the trade options available to you but other times, and a few times there will be amazing offers that will provide you with great boosts to your economy. You need to keep an eye out. It is a good idea but can be somewhat inconsistent. Your island will constantly ship out the materials that you need instead of keeping it on island. Some buildings, such as the cannery, are a nightmare and will bog down your entire island. Kalypso must iron out balance issues between buildings and fixing small issues such as entire islands getting bogged down because teamsters stop working.

The swiss bank account still has very few/no uses.

reviewText: I recommend this game for anyone who enjoys its style of gameplay. While there may be some glitches or features which people disagree with, I believe that they are worth overlooking simply for the enjoyment of being a dictator and having to build a country against real issues. I am not a fan of being overly critical of games, and if a game gives me the slightest bit of enjoyment, then I think it is worthwhile, and I can definitely say that this game has been enjoyable to me so far. The developers created a great game, and it is a shame that some people cannot look past small mistakes or glitches. There is a massive distinction between degrading complaint and constructive criticism.

reviewText:
Is it different? Absolutely. Yet, as a long time fan of the series, I can honestly suggest this game. (I got it on sale for $10, and I suggest you get in on sale as well). I really just enjoy the content of this series, and this game is a decent enough continuation of the series.


A few things off the top of my head...
The UI is different than Troico 4, but one eventually get's use to it.
The graphics have improved thanks to utilizing DX11
Almost every building is upgradable, and you can upgrade some all at once (if you have the money)
Dynasty Members, not really all that great, but you can pick and choose traits to suit your needs (and use them as managers)
There are tons of buildings to choose from.
Along with the eras you progress through, you have to do research to unlock different things (buildings, edicts, etc.)
Farms are more contained and you know where the crops will grow (as opposed to randomly around the building)

If you enjoyed the first 4 Tropico games (Like me), then I'd be shocked if you didn't find at least something enjoyable about this game.

*I agree with most everyone about the DLC being horribly overpriced and refuse to buy them (I bought standalone before the Complete collection was released). Maybe if they bundle them at a huge discount...

reviewText:
Tropico 5 is not quite as good of a Tropico game as it's predecessors, however, it is a better city-builder. Tropico still maintains much of it's comedy and charm but, unfortunately, something feels like it is missing since Tropico 4.

The new interface leaves much to be desired as much of the information that El Presidente's are used to is now either buried or missing. Want to know which buildings are profitable and full? Too bad. Want to know where the oil is? Use a magnifying glass! The lack of a Tropico 4 style interface leaves much to be desired and makes it difficult to get the information you need.

It also seems that with the addition of the new interface we've also lost the fun faction interaction that we've come to expect. They do still exist but they've essentially taken a back seat to everything and are much harder to find with much fewer missions.

The addition of the new dynasty system is pretty cool. Your new family members offer you some nice bonuses, more benefits, and you can use them as new 'managers' which help you run buildings better. You can even send them on fun little missions and storyline quests for more bonuses. However, with the addition of these new folks you also lose direct control of El Presidente himself. You can no longer tell him where to go, who to visit, and what store to promote. I used to LOVE that feature from Tropico 4 and it helped pass the time and improve production. Now all El Presidente does is wonder around like an NPC. Furthermore, you also have a lot less options in character creation when it comes to El Presidente and can no longer pick from a vast number of backgrounds, histories, bonuses, and penalties; now you pick ONE bonus and that's it.

As I said, Tropico 5 is likely the best city builder of the series. The addition of the new grid or city layout system makes placing and organizing structures MUCH easier. Due to the new era system you also have building that grow and change as time passes. Farms, for example, get nice upgrades and then can be transformed into Hydroponic Farms which are much smaller and more efficient.

Overall, I have been enjoying Tropico as a good city builder but I often miss the micromanagement, humor, and the style of Tropico 4. Everyone expects at least a dozen DLCs (ten confirmed so far) and I hope that future patches improve Tropico 5 back up to Tropico 4's level.

Well... As a sequel to tropico 4 there's quite a lot of things that have improved and things that haven't been improved or made worse. Here are some of them:

+ New features

Not worth the money especially with all the DLC. If you wanna buy it buy it on some steam sale or something.

reviewText:
Tropico is a series of city builders lite where you are also a dictator (a pirate lord in 2) who has to stay in power while trying to build his little heaven (or hell) on Earth.

And whereas Tropico 4 was just a Tropico 3 with more stuff - Tropico 5 has many features changed, reworked, added (and some cut) to warrant being called a proper sequel. Oh and it also has MUCH more stuff to do.

With changes in economy and many product chains and raw resources added compared to the previous game - it may take a few failures to wrap your head around the way things work.
Your tropical dictator paradise can now also have sharper teeth with more offensive stuff to beat down rebels and invaders with (although with changes in faction system the rebellions happen a lot more often for my taste).
All other categories of things to build and create are expanded as well, coming with a lot more comfortable interface.

As usual Sandbox mode is where the real game's at. And now it doesn't have time limits, albeit the generator is unfortunately simplified.
Instead the time frame takes you through four eras starting with colonial one where you are just a mere local manager of the king - you have to use crown's cash to kickstart your playground which you also have to make independent before your term's over. Don't worry it can be extended by doing missions (later on they give you much more varied rewards).
Of course if you don't want to bother with the colonial era (with it being quite different from the rest of the game, but I personally like it) - you can pick any other era to begin your game in.

I recommend it both to newcomers and previous Tropico players alike.

reviewText:
I was introduced to the Tropico franchise around the time when the newest Sim City came out. Sim City was a massive dud and Calypso Games decided to capitalize with a 75% sale on Tropico 4. When Tropico 5 came around I was ready for more. I enjoyed Tropico 5 immensely. All the annoying little bits of Tropico 4 were wiped away and the new game style was great. Having to plan a city to last the entire franchise mode was fun. I got attached to my cities. I recommend Tropico 5.

Then I downloaded 'The Big Cheese' DLC. It was 5 bucks for a silly costume, new building, and extra missions. It was a ripoff  but I was still loving Tropico so much I didn't care. The building was decent. I could never find the costume. The mission was impossible. I mean IMPOSSIBLE. I normally build my cities to use the resources well and keep my people happy. I tried this with the mission and failed to finish it within the time allotted. Begrudgingly I lowered the difficulty down to east and tried again. I failed. I was a little confused at what I was doing wrong. A month later I decided to load it up again and go for it one last time. I screwed over my citizens in the name of milk. I built as many of the creameries as possible and put all my resources into pumping out as much as possible. I failed. I see this as lazy game design. They made a great game and now are trying to just cash in until Tropico 6 comes around.

Get the game. Skip the Expansions.

reviewText:
Tropico 5
~~~~~~~

This series is getting better with each sequel.

Of course you have to build and reach your objectives as usual but in Tropico 5 you have more options than before. From customizing your El Presidente, hiring manager to your building, finding technology and much more.  Using the tutorial is actually a good idea to be honest.

But do not worry; you can actually set the level of difficulty easily.

Visually, this game is beautiful and run smoothly. The soundtrack is a pleasure to your ears as we would expect from this franchise.

My only criticism is with the control, I am wondering why the gamepad is the primary control.  To me this type of game is so much better with your keyboard and mouse. Saying this, you can play with the keyboard and mouse but it is not smooth in my opinion.

Positives:
~~~~~~~
-	Visually splendid
-	Fantastic soundtracks
-	Plenty things to do
-	Setup your levels of difficulties (political, economic, etc) before you start each mission
-	Challenging
-	Achievements
-	Trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Gamepad as primary control

Overall this game is a solid 8 out of 10 (just because of the gamepad), Otherwise I would give it a 10 out of 10.

Well done El Presidente!

reviewText:
Tropico 5 contains some substantial improvements over the previous two in the series (because face it, Tropico 4 was really just Tropico 3 with a few bells and whistles added.)

Most notably, Tropicans do not have to be physically present in a building for the building to be active-- meaning that the year and a half of downtime while Tropicans wandered over to the Cigar factory to actually earn their pay is now gone. This results in a much smoother economic development.

The second big change is that the campaign is not just a story woven through some otherwise disconnected scenario maps. When you finish a scenario in the campaign, your island is saved so that when you return to it*, all your buildings and Tropicans are in the same place.

The third item of note is that within the campaign, the progression of time is usually not measured as the passage of months within a year (ex. Nov. 1959) but is instead a countdown to an event related to the scenario (ex. 48 months left before mandate expires) which you can usually extend in several different ways while playing.

reviewText: I am thoroughly enjoying this game.  I have  played all of the previous versions of tropico and this one is obviously a new generation separate from the older titles. It is more difficult, and it does not run on older machines. However, I am on mission number 4 of the single player campaign and have been having a really good time playing.  I recommend it to any strategy game fans out there. I like that your old builds remain in place- it makes long term planning more important.  I have also found that the military is something you need to pay much more attention to-- which is fine in my book. After all, why play a banana republic dictator if you  don't have to rely on soldiers to keep you in power?  I heartily recommend it to all fans of sims or  strategy games. The graphics and sound are top notch. Of course they will expect you to  pay  for downloadable content in the future, but this is nothing new for those who have prior tropico titles.

reviewText:
The newness of new Tropico:
- time passes. Different tech in different time periods. To level up the time you have to achieve different stuff. Start in colonial times and move to modern times.
- tech up. You have to research the technologies to unlock them.
- fog of war. Before a certain technology is unlocked you have to explore your island to be able to use it.
- dynasty members. You level up your dude and his family for bonuses
- more battles. Military actually matters cause you get attacked for more reasons than riots.
- managers in buildings. You can discover and hire managers to improve and specialize buildings
- building upgrades. There are a ton of ways to customize and level up almost every building.
- more complicated trading. Lots of trade ships and trade routes so you can play an import export game if you want or smuggle or whatevs. Also political rating affects what trade routes you have available.
- fun campaign. It involves time travel and stuff.
- multiplayer mode. Which I have not tried yet but would like to...
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Fans of the series will be satisfied with this entry, unless you are motivated with the idea of enjoying the new multiplayer mode. As of today's release, multiplayer does not include the ability to either A) save the game, or B) increase/decrease the speed of the game. While one would only hope that the lack of these features is a mere oversight that will be corrected in future patches, it seems foolhardy to count on it.\n\nIn short, if the multiplayer is important to you, it would be wise to hold off on Tropico 5.

reviewText:
I've been playing Tropico games since the third one. I still haven't played the first and second Tropico games though I might pick them up on the next sale just to see how the game has changed over the years. I enjoy Tropico 3 and 4 a lot but Tropico 5 is by far my favorite with all of the changes that have been made to make it more of a enjoyable and challenging game. If you've played Tropico then skip the next paragraph.

For those who are unfamiliar with Tropico, you play El Presidente, the dictator of the island of Tropico. You can play the game as a leader of the people, doing everything to please them, or you can bribe, cheat and kill your way through your lifetime (If you choose to have it end). You'll face rebels, foreign powers, protestors, and elections as you play a much more humorious city building simulator. While I enjoyed Tropico 3, when I got the fourth installment I could tell the developers knew how to improve their game and did what people wanted by adding more of well, everything and included the humor that made Tropico 4 even more enjoyable. However one thing remained unchanged, Tropico has a issue named after it. The issue is once you know what to do the game becomes way too easy and the other problems being builds stop being built by the NPCs (Luckily happens later in so you can insta-build everything) and the worst issue being that shipments stop being transported for some reason. These issue have been taken care of in Tropico 5, however in the Modern Era sometimes I run into issues with the Teamsters again.

Tropico 5 adds new features like the time era and research to help keep things from getting too easy. It has you create a constitution that will help and hurt you in various ways. Importing and exporting goods go far more indept, allowing you to choose who you buy and sell to for each individual good to get the best prices and help (and hurt) your relations with foreign powers. For example, in the World War Era, if you sell to the Allies it will hurt the Axis' view of you which can lead to less trade with them and if your relation with them is bad enough, an invasion.

Old things like your military buildings are far more useful in this game. Before they were only good for when rebels attack. Now they'll help you with foreign invasion (which before ment Game Over) and pirates when they attack you for your gold. You also won't get that one soldier that just turns into Rambo because they end up killing everyone attacking by themselves. They also add a Manager" system. Most of the building can have a manager and depending on who you pick will give you certain bonuses
date: like increasing housing quality nearby or increase production.\n\nWith all of the improvments made
recommended: the game has become noticably harder. No more is re-election a definite thing. The player could be making large amounts of spending money but if your people are not pleased
hoursPlayed: come time for re-election it could mean Game Over. And with no speeches this time to save you (Though might be nice to add something where if you don't keep your promises it'll hurt you in the long run might be good) you may find yourself bribing and exicuting faction leaders more often. I know I did. In Tropico 3 and 4 I never did but here I find myself cheating the votes and taking care of the faction leaders just to end up winning by no more than 30 votes. The game is fair about it though. I've won before having 80% of the votes before
voteText: what you do can make or break you here and I love it.\n\nThere are other things like an online multiplayer which I haven't tried out fully yet but given the way the game plays

reviewText:
So, Tropico 5. We meet at last. Do you know why you were brought here, Tropico #5? Because El Presidente believes with the right sort of, let's say, motivation, you could become so much more useful as a citizen of our great virtual island. But as it is right now? I don't know, Tropico 5. I don't know. Considering the work of the four previous Tropicos who have come through town, who have very rarely made any significant changes to the status quo, which I have to admit, around here we can appreciate that sort of slow gradual change considering how everything has been working just fine, you decided you wanted to make a few more, shall we say, radical changes. This has El Presidente very concerned. Let's go over the dossier, shall we?

Let's start with what you've been doing around town that's got so many fellow citizens vocally supporting you. One of the biggest changes you've made is to the infrastructure. It's nice to see that you've scaled down the size of the parking garages to something manageable, and look, in the Modern area you've introduced the Metro to our tiny island! Letting citizens get from one point of the island to the other nearly instantaneously is quite the feet. Something that El Presidente truly appreciates when he wants to get out to the llama farms for some quite and relaxation without having to drive through all of that horrible traffic. Which is another issue we see significantly less of. It is good to see more people walking instead of filling the streets with cars! I applaud you, Tropico 5, for finally resolving that issue.

That reminds me, the whole Era thing. It is, if of a somewhat debatable quality, nice to have Eras from which to transition. Going from the Colonial Era to the World War Era is probably the largest change of the four. The other two are the Cold War and the Modern Era. Having the ability to upgrade certain residential units to other certain residential units is nice as the era transitions, and new constructions become available.Having Edicts become available as the Era progresses is another thing to look forward to, until finally you have access to all of them. And the Constitution! Who would have expected something like that to be introduced into our tiny island? The discovery of science, which is used to enhance the Constitution and advance the Eras, was nice as we can finally figure out that whole sliced bread thing.

The price of docks is considerable cheaper than they were previously, which allows El Presidente to build many, many docks to help speed up the export of his new delicious cheese. And speaking of money, it's nice to finally be able to have a use for El Presidente's, shall we say 'private' income. Being able to use the Swiss Bank account balance level up El Presidente and his family members abilities is quite good at encouraging you to play multiple maps with the same family so you realize their full power! Oh yes, and El Presidente would like me to pass along his thanks in allowing multiple members of the family to share power on our island.

For the workforce, being able to hire managers with minor Presidente-like powers to manage buildings is a nice touch indeed. The people of our island enjoy being empowered in such a way that makes them more useful to El Presidente.

But now onto some concerning trends that I am seeing here. The buildings snap to a rather large grid system that while nice when fitting buildings together sometimes, is terrible unimaginative and can leave a lot of extra space between buildings where they meet at odd angles. It doesn't help any that you have taken away El Presidente's favorite toys. No longer can we build statues to honor El Presidente's might. No, now parks and decorations only come in two units, small and large. The small is one grid or two, while the large fluctuates slightly more, starting at a 4x4, and going to such sizes as 4x6, to the mighty 5x5 and 5x6. But what happened to the gardeners, Tropico 5? Did you murder them in the study with a lead pipe? Because we can no longer plant individual trees, or benches, or any of the small single items. This is a great disappointment to El Presidente, for he had quite the green-thumb.

Housing has now turned into something of a mess, since, as we said, Tropicans walk far more than they did last time. Now if a Tropican can not find a house near where they live, they will opt to just build a shack near their work-site, even if there is ample housing on the island. I have been told by many who do this, Tropico #5, that they were encouraged to ignore El Presidente's benevolence and build these eyesores around the city by you.

And another thing. Why have you taken away the ability of El Presidente to personally manage the wages of our citizens? Not only that, but he can no longer set prices for buildings or services. Everything has instead been rolled up into one budget" function. Tropico 5
date: I'm concerned about this power grab. These are function that should be left up to El Presidente himself to manage
recommended: not some overly simplified "budget bar" that controls everything. This has actually made it HARDER to manage the economy
hoursPlayed: since if we want to pay people less

reviewText:
This game makes for a great city builder with a comic twist. Previous Tropico titles were also very fun and time-consuming, but with the new edicts, tweaked economy and the added eras, this game has evolved quite well. Though it takes a while even for the somewhat experienced Tropico player to get into it, it's well worth it.

The colonial era is an enjoyable starting position where you focus on raw materials before becoming an industrial powerhouse. Previous titles always made you start with minimun buildings in 1950, but this gives your island nation a colonial tradition as well. New military buildings and modes allow you to repel rebel attacks and fight off foreign invasions.

Multiplayer is fun! Co-op or fight your friends is great, but as both cities reach around a 1,000 population, connection issues are immenent. This still needs fixing, but overall, multiplayer is pretty great!

So far, I have played several sandbox games with varying settings and one multiplayer game with a friend. I have listed several pro's and cons below:

Pro's:

Colonial Start - Great feel and well suited to the game. Every island in the caribbean has an extensive colonial history. Glad Tropico is now one of them :) You can already experience 15k + profits with every freighter which will allow easy and fast industrialization in the next era.

Resource and Manufacture Diversity - New minerals and raw resources, more factory goods and more production cycles, with the opportunity to elaborate and initiate new production cycles: Coal to Oil, Oil to Pharmeceuticals; Cocoa, sugar and milk to chocolate milk, etc.

Trading System - Profit from extra trading deals for your resources and manufacture. A big plus as this can sometimes lead to incredible boosts to economy. Though these offers appear and disappear over time, it's worth checking your trade tab every few months.

Elaborate Tourism - A diversity in the amount of tourists reflects in the many hotels that one can build. Different buildings add to appeal for different types of tourists. You'll decide to place buildings in particular places that will increase effectiveness of buildings: Haciendas and historical inns near colonial buildings; economy hotels and cabana villages near your entertainment hotspots; country hotels and cabins in the middle of nowhere, etc.


Cons:

Limited Ruling Options - In previous titles you could choose several ways to rule. Background info for your character could make a great difference. I feel with the constitution options this has actually been limited if you want to make most out of your island. When encountering different constitution choices, there three options, but it two are opposites of each other and the third a more-or-less neutral stance on the subject. I personally feel this limits options.

Traffic - With more teamsters in each era, traffic becomes a total nightmare in Modern Times. Any junction, even three way junctions, already halts most traffic. Even if you have more than enough teamsters, goods sometimes don't reach buildings for some time, even if your road layout is quite good. Hopefully they will add future options to add rotundas, yielding signs, trafficlights etc to aid traffic flow.

Music - All music has become instrumental. Whilst that is not per sé a bad thing, I do feel Tropico loses it's Hispanic touch in that sense. Tropico 3 and 4 both had excellent OSTs, whilst I feel that Tropico 5's soundtrack is a bit more repetitive and just not quite as fun. Best soundtrack is still Tropico 3. Venga bailar! xD

Overall:
A great game if you like the series or city builders. The game needs some more elaboration, but I'm confident new DLC will be available soon enough. For now, Tropico 5 offers enough to ease the gaming experience. Va a su proximo aventura, presidente!

reviewText:
First, a brief history lesson. I was an avid player of Tropico 3, and snatched Tropico 4 up on the first day. I was underwhelmed, as the game seemed more to be Tropico 3.75 than a new game in its own right; for example, all of the UI and art elements were exactly the same. However, over the next several years, patches and DLC helped make Tropico 4 a truly outstanding game, far surpassing its predecessor.

Now we're met with Tropico 5, and history seems to be repeating itself. Tropico 5 has a rock-solid foundation. The mechanics and the underlying systems have been streamlined and now make a lot more sense. Building variety has been diminished, but gone are a lot of buildings that you only ever used once (and that was just to find out what it did). What's left has a time and a place, and the only time you won't use a building is if it doesn't suit your playstyle (as opposed to, say, satellite dishes from Tropico 4, which had very little extra-campaign utility). I've yet to experience a crash. The new systems function well. I especially like the introduction of eras. The dynasty system works, I think. I'm not sure. I seem to get all of the bonuses all of the time, regardless of who is Presidente.

That said, the game needs work. Some categories (entertainment) are far too sparse, unless you want a dozen cabarets on your island. I've experienced one game-breaking bug: I don't win Sandbox missions despite meeting the victory conditions. Hopefully that gets patched soon. Upgrading buildings is tedious, although I'm happy that they streamlined modernizing them. A big letdown is that the trademark Tropico humour largely falls flat this time around. Instead of the caricatures of various tropes (the drunken priest, the inept second-in-command) and the banter on the radio which could be genuinely funny (I still laugh at General Rodriguez's description of the Museum of Modern Art), you get Brokeback Mountain" references
recommended: and...Lulu. One cannot be told what Lulu is
hoursPlayed: one must experience her awfulness for oneself.\n\nAll told
voteText: it's a solid game that will likely only get better as time goes on. It's worth the price--you can easily get 30-40 hours of gameplay in its current state. It's still one of the best city-builder franchises out there."

reviewText: Having owned and spent countless hours playing Tropico 3, I was skeptical as to whether it'd be worth buying Tropico 5 or not. I wasn't sure if I'd just be purchasing an upgraded and updated edition of the game. However, upon review, spending the money for this game was definately worth it. The mechanics and graphics are smooth and to a high quality, and the replayability is of course high for a game of this calibre. Whilst I have yet to successfully complete a sandbox game without utter chaos and uprisings against my dictatorships, trying a new approach everytime will allow me to spend countless more hours in this game. 9/10, definately recommend for any RTS / City Sim fan.

reviewText:
Buy Tropico 4, not 5 if you want to have fun owning your own island.

There are many small annoyances with this new entry to the series. For instance sometimes it feels like I'd rather pull my fingernails off than try getting roads placed where I want in this game. Same goes for buildings, especially on shore regions.
What makes this task even more frustrating is the new fog of not knowing your own island" which can be painstakingly cleared by sending your palace troops to "explore" said areas. Only that the troops are idiots that don't reveal important areas (mines
date: oil) but rather walk right past them. Have fun sending them again and again (1000 credits every time) to reveal even the smallest of areas. These guys are like Vickers in Prometheus
recommended:
capable running only straight ahead - except when they can use roads to go around and reveal even less of fogged area than using straight path to marker.

The "combat" in this game... whoo boy. Not good. not good at all since you can't control the troops at all and the outcome is based on placement of your building in relation to path taken by attacking forces. What fun.

A new console-player friendly task system within campaign missions is like you're playing a tutorial all the time. Do this and do just to get some reward. What happened to being supreme leader? In this game you're just an errand boy.

Campaign missions end on victory condition
hoursPlayed: just to kick you to another island for one mission and then back to the first one. Around we go. Not the smoothest experience and feels like a continuation of tutorial feeling described above.\n\nExecution is poor and overall Tropico 4 is so much better than this its not even funny."

reviewText:
I don't think this is a terrible game, and if you're bored or not worried about the cash - sure, buy it.

But it's not great.  I think the series (or developer) has gone a little bit creatively bankrupt .. clearly struggling to find new ways to reinvent the game.  (Which, strictly speaking, I don't think you need to do - you can just improve on the existing formula).

What I mean is - rather than look for substantial changes, make iterative ones - make the underlying financial simulation stronger, make the graphics better, make the islands larger ... and then make it all about the story-telling and controlled challenges in the scenario.

Instead, it feels like they've kind of tried to reinvent a bit .. consolidating concepts that came up in Tropico 4 DLCs (like changing eras) and introduce them into this game.  Problem is it all feels shallow.  There's this dynasty concept where you can have children, raise them, have them fulfil roles in your dynasty (but you yourself don't die, apparently).  There's just .. I don't know .. a shallowness to it all that makes you start yawning before you're even halfway through the game.

They've also left core elements out of the game, and a lot of the stuff that made Tropico 4 interesting (such as balancing the factions) has been de-emphasised in Tropico 5.

It feels to me that Tropico 5 is kind of like the wanna-be cool grandad of Tropico 4 .. it's actually older and less edgy, but it tries to dress up in a younger persons clothes and act cool .. but you can kind of tell it's struggling to keep up the charade and running out of ideas.

It was hard to decide whether YES I DO recommend this game or NO I DON'T.  For me it's marginal .. if you're looking for a city builder with it's own personality, why not ?  It's not a terri-♥♥♥♥ game .. it's just not great.

reviewText:
I did like Tropico 3 and Tropico 4. In fact I loved them!. However, Tropico 5 was, let's say, different.

The graphics were good and the humour was there too (if not a bit repetative, a joke is funny once, twice, three times, four times -cringe, again, again and so on). Too little dialogue was included.

I'm sorry to say the gameplay just didn't work. What do I mean by that? Well, it was boring by comparison!

One of the features that unfortunatly dictate how the game is played, is that each scenario is played on a different island. That in itself is not a problem, but two or three scenarios later you go back to the island that you previously developed and you have to try and remember how and where all the resources are and how you developed the 'supply chain'. It was like going back into somebody elses half-played game and trying to work out what's wrong with it - even though it worked when you left it!!!

The menus are at times difficult to work with - important features, that can make or break a game, are sometimes buried deep in a menu that you hardly use or struggle to find (even though you might remember it was somewhere).

My next comment is strange, yes I agree. But it is like the rebels and armies are random. Now I know that they are not. But I felt like they were detached from what I was doing even though I do understand the mechanics.

I have saved my biggest gripe/problem until last. Groan. The price of the DLC's!!! I paid a lot of money for this game £35. Nobody should have to pay a total of an additional £52 for all the DLc's) making the cost of this game a humongous £87 (about $135 american dollars as I write this). This was a huge problem for me IN THIS GAME. Because I felt that I did not get the gameplay that I should have had from the original package and the content just wasn't there!!!

I am not against all DLC's. But these were overpriced and the original game was short of too many features. So I did not buy them.

The original base game is on SALE now at £12.24.
I believe £14.99 would be fair price, maybe.......... BUT this price should certainly include all the smaller DLC's. Maybe £19.99 with all the DLC's included. So it is still not good value even at 50% off.

If it was reduced to these prices tomorrow would I buy them? I'm sorry no, for all resons that I wrote about above. The game does not compare to the fun that Tropico 3 and 4 were and I tired very quickly from it.

reviewText:
Economy building game type thingy. The game looks nice, but as a fan of the genre I do have some gripes with it. First of, it is rather shallow compared to feature packed games like Unknown Horizons or Sim City. Since I'm now used to playing high quality strategy games like that (some for free), I expect commercial titles to go the extra mile.

Placing roads is akward at best. Yes, you learn to work around it, but a user interface should work for the player, not against him. During multiplayer you can build roads that stretch far out, but they cannot be demolished leaving you no room to make a single mistake while placing them. That is a tall order considering how akward the road editing is.
The game rushes you from era to era and I often struggle to remain in one era because I feel I haven't gotten to use my newly researched technologies enough. This combined with very small map sizes (even huge is rather small compared to other games) makes it a poor choice for the month long builds I'm used to.

There is supposedly a way to save/load multiplayer games, but it's not clear to me at this point exactly how. As with seemingly all modern games, it lacks a proper server browser, instead your left with some social network thing for matchmaking and remote hosting. I didn't like it in L4D2 and I don't like it in this game either. Really old games like OpenTTD (which is free) solved load, save and multiplayer features a long time ago. Just do what they did.

The game has also crashed a few times, not a segfault, but a hard lock forcing me to get a console up to kill it.

reviewText:
I was hesitant to buy this game at first because of the reviews but I went ahead and got it anyway because it was on sale and I love the Tropico franchise. This is now my favorite tropico so far.

This game got me just as hooked as the others, and hands down it is the most in-depth and complex tropico so far.

They have introduced dynasties so you can have additonal characters and vote other dynasty members in during elections and take advantage of their bonuses. Moving the character around to give boosts to buildings has been eliminated. I see this as a good thing because it just seemed like unecessary micromanagement in the previous game. Instead your character or dynasty members give global boosts to production or whatever else they do (military strength, effectiveness of services, etc.)

They have also overhauled trading and added trade routes which can be very profitable if you find good opportunites (Not every trade is profitable and sometimes settling for less lucrative ones is desirable.) They are very easy to manage and not annoying at all. Docks are now more useful to provide more ships for trade routes.

The difficulty of the game has gone up, which is a good thing for me because in previous installments I'd get bored when I had loads of cash and almost 100% happiness. In this game I've actually had to use my military AND do the voter fraud thing. I had never had to do that in previous games. You no longer need a secret service building to do certain things, which I thought was pretty annoying.

They've introduced a constitution which give you decisions to make that will benefit your country. There is no more immigration building but the benefits provided by one are instead on a constitutional amendment. Edicts are basically the same but some have to be unlocked through research. They've also added research, and it's not just buying blueprints like before. Building libraries and staffing them give research points.

Armies and military are very important now and are to be utilized. In previous games I would not bother with militaries until the militant faction complained, in this game it is very handy to have a sizable military, especially when declaring independence in the colonial era.

There are now multiple eras in the game. I did not have the modern times expansion from Tropico 4 so I will not compare them directly, but the eras add a whole new interesting layer. In the colonial era you should try to increase revolutionary support to buy independence from the crown and move on to the great war era. This is where the military can also come in handy, to declare independence the crown requests $20,000. If you have a sizable military you can refuse and fight off the crowns troops to save that money. It's not extremely difficult to do and is somewhat challenging but it was a lot of fun for me to do.

Farms and mines are also much different. Farms are much more asthetically pleasing and larger. The way building upgrades work has also been changed and is more relevant early game. It's not just a statistical advantage to get late game anymore. A previous reviewer has complained about the way the mine looks, but I think it looks much much better than before. Instead of a random patch of land being dug into, mines are now in preselected locations along mountains.

Wages & rents are more simple to manage, no longer do you set individual rents or wages but you set budgets which determine worker prosperity. I do not think I can explain it well, but if you set budgets high, the workers income level becomes either poor, well-off, rich, etc. This determines what kind of house they live in.

There is now a fog of war" type mechanic on the island. In the colonial and great war era you need to explore your island to reveal what resources you have available. You use your military for this.

The game runs just as well
recommended:
than the previous version of Tropico. I honestly think it runs better than Tropico 4 did on my laptop which is surprising. I also feel comfortable hooking the laptop up to the TV and playing this tropico from my couch with my wireless laptop & keyboard. The GUI had been changed and is much better. I also like that they changed the portraits on the message screens. It's not as exaggerated and cartoony as it was before. I also feel like I can't zoom in on my island as far as I used to.

Cons: Only bad things I think is that there is no real additional building sprites. I thought this would be something easy to do. The almanac also has a little less info available but the data that it does show is much more useful and better organized than before.

I highly recommend it for anybody who likes the Tropico series. I have been playing since Tropico 2 and this one is my favorite so far. Definitely buy
hoursPlayed: even at full price."

reviewText:
Been playing Tropico 5 for a week now and I must say, though on the surface this game looks like a step in the right direction the inside of this game is 100 steps back.

Pros:
-Longer game time from the new dynasty eras. (Colonial, World Wars, Cold War, Modern Times)
-New ways to power your government through your new constitution
-Add members of your family to your government for extra benefits
-Bigger islands that need exploring before you can just build anywhere
-Multiplayer (All we ever wanted, right?)

Cons:
-Lacking in everything everywhere (explained below)
-Every model of each building is the exact same unlike Tropico 4 where you could change the way they looked.
-No more loyalist (my personal favorit faction in T4. no more hardcore dictatorships favoring your loyal subjects)
-No more prisons/labor camps to lock away the people against you
-No more decorations for your city (Statues of your self, national flag, you know that fun silly stuff)
-Only about 5 outfits to choose from all of them worst than the other (Where is my traditional flag suit?)
-The Almac is just a tad harder to navigate in (just considering the amout of clicks it takes to find what im looking for)
-You cant choose a back story or how the Presidente rose to power anymore (just one and ONLY one stat)
-YOU CANT SAVE YOUR MUTIPLAYER GAMES (Who let this one happen?)  -_-

I could really just go on and on about how much I really dont like this game. I am beyond dissapointed, this is almost scam worthy. If you already own Tropico 4 and your thinking of getting 5 please, do yourself a favor and walk away, im begging you. Dont fall for this game and it lies. Terrible just terrible.

reviewText: All I have to say, despite my rather dull and uninteresting life, at least I can forget about my troubles and focus on my private tropical island when I am down!  Amazing game, it really is!  The ONLY minor complaint I have, and in comarison with the rest of the game it is minor, is I wish we had more control over the various attributes of the dictator like we did in Tropico 4.....  Other than that, Penultimo is hilarious, the music is awesome, building and learning what you are doing is a breeze!  The tutrial is very useful, earning medals is a blast, the economics are balanced and very interesting, and the downloadable content after you buy the game is endless!!!  Far as multiplayer, I have to wonder why every time I try and find an opponent, there are not enough people to play.... but that being said, there is so much else you can do after you finish the campaigns I would STILL say incredible replayablility!  and on top of it all.... I managed to grab my copy for 10 dollars when it was on sale at STEAM..... everyone needs to check this game out!!!

reviewText:
This is by far the worst Tropico (excluding Tropico 2 off course). There is nothing left of the original charme of Tropico 1.

The developers have introduced several new concepts but every single one of them is implemented poorly. It doesn't feel right. The UI, campaign, dynasty, research, combat and trading feel like they don't belong. And some of the old core mechanics seem to have vanished or are broken.

I have played every Tropico there is and  I had high hopes. But this is a big disappointment. Tropico 4 is way better and Tropico 1 is still better then both of them.

Even the music has lost its Cuban flair.

I would describe it as a poor mixture between Anno and the last SimCity.

reviewText:
Tropico 5 is still a Tropico game through and through, although it is a slight step below Tropico 4.

There has been a lot of reviews that say that Tropico 4 is better, and it is, but Tropico 5 is still a fun game and that doesn't mean you should skip it.

In Tropico you still play as a lovable dictator leading his latin america island to glory. You have to manage the economy, population happiness, military defence and politics in order to survive.

There is flexibility in what economy you want, whether it be exporting raw materials like iron and coffee, turning them into goods like steel or canned food, or tourism.

Politics is more advanced than in Tropico 4, where you have the Constitution which affects your country in different ways, and what you choose will affect your standings with the external world powers and also the internal factions in your country.

The things that Tropico 4 did better are little things like Penultimo being voiced by a goofy hilarious voice actor, but in Tropico 5 he sounds like a monotonous person with no charisma.
Tropico 4 also had nice music with the singing, but Tropico 5 doesn't.
These little things however create the funny and fun atmosphere that Tropico is famed for, and something that is slightly missing in Tropico 5.

Overall Tropico 5 is still a good game for people who love the franchise. But if you have never played Tropico 4, that game may be more worth your money.

reviewText: The only other Tropico game I have tried was the very first one, which was interesting. This game; However, I found thoroughly enjoyable, though I can't quite explain why. It was fun playing a Quasi-dictator who tried running a democratic state, while juggling the many scenario surprises such as, Russian Invasions, Tsunami destruction, Tornado's, Rebel attacks, Riots and having multiple foreign powers crying for my attention. I spent several hours just getting lost going through each faction member, playing with my population by bribing, arresting, or banishing them to see what would happen. The graphics are not bad, and the mods and add-on content such as, Waterborne add content to make the game even more enjoyable. All in all, I would recommend this game for those who enjoy this type of game. It is worth multiple playthroughs using various tactics.

reviewText: Honestly, I was just expecting more from this release. I completely finished the campaign of Tropico 4 and love the hell out of it, but I feel like this game was built on the same engine. They reuse the same animations and camera angles from Tropico 4 for a ton of things that happen regularly, like tsunamis. The game doesn't look noticeably better than Tropico 4, and there aren't really even many new building types. The only new additions are a research tree which is ultimately a waste of time because it doesn't give you meaningful upgrades, the ability to apply managers to buildings based on certain traits (it's a really passive thing), and what else, the islands stay the same from level to level? Both of them. Furthermore, the game runs sort of poorly. All in all, if you can get this for cheap and haven't played the previous entries to death already, go for it. Otherwise, save your money and your time.
