reviewText:
Lately I've been holding off on reviewing many things, due to the nature of many games being worked on continuously and things changing very fluidly.

Today I write a big thumbs up for the Tropico 5 team for pulling through on two things that many in the community thought they had ripped us off on.

The first, prisons. Why these weren't there at launch is beyond me, considering they were in Tropico 3 & 4, the community thought perhaps we would get nickled and dimed for a prison DLC. The dev team to the surprise of many, at patch 1.08, have hadded the prison and the ability to arrest citizens for FREE.

In addition to this, the second large complaint was the 2000 population limit. Tropico 5 offers various huge Islands for the players to build on, much of which would stay empty due to the low population limit. Not to mention the horrible side effect of this limit and multiplayer - in which the total cap was divided among all players. New with patch 1.08 is the ability to change the max population anywhere between the original 2000, and the new high limit of 10,000.

I have to say I am very happy to see the devs change their stance on the population cap after community feedback, and would highly recommend this game to anyone. It's done a lot for the series, and is very unique in its approach compared to T3 & T4. Not to mention the devs, while a little slow on the action point here, nontheless pulled through for the community.

With my restored faith I may just buy the large upcomming DLC at full price :)

reviewText:
Really funny city simulator.

The campaign is solid and its objectives are really nice.

There are several different (and all valid) options to get fast cash, from farms to factories, from tourism to offices.

In this game you are the people manager, for real - not only the buildings positioner -, you need to understand how many educated citizen you have (high school and university), how many not educated, and how your economic development choices will impact on the high school / not educated ratio - for example a farm based economy just needs not educated ppl / a offices based economy needs all ppl from university.

Besides the education the population is sorted by age, wealth and preferences, since the population is divided in factions, often asking the opposites, like nationalists vs globalists.

During my almost 40 hours play-through I experimented several different economies and I had fun with them all, which is the most important thing to me.

To succeed you have to find the right balances between multiple contemporary conditions, all spiced up by random disasters and the various rebellions / invasions.

Suggesting the game, my personal score is 8/10

reviewText:
Fun with some neat aspects, but not as good as Tropico 4. Worth getting if you want to play multiplayer.

It seems that there were a number of things removed from Tropico 5 (such as different characters for faction leaders and your parliment/cabinet members), but it's balanced out by the things it does add (like different eras, Colonial/World Wars/Cold War/Modern).

Pick this game up on a sale for sure. Or pick up Tropico 4.

reviewText:
Very good game, and a nice sequel to Tropico 4!
+ Campaign
The campaign in T5 is quite demanding. I found myself lowering the difficulty level in some missions, due to... the wrong decisions made in the previous ones (the maps transfer themselves to the next missions, so wrong decisions made in e.g. 3rd mission can cause problems in the 5th). Although quite frustrating at first try, I find this feature a nice addtion to the strategic part of the game :)
+ Humour
I've never laughed so hard while playing Tropico! The new lines said by the characters (especially Penultimo) are great! The humour presented in T5 is much better than the one present in T4, which was also very good.
+ Graphics
Wow, I was really surpised by the level of this game's graphics! They are not the best in the gaming industry, but they are one of the best in the strategy genre.
- Dynasty
Positively surprised at first glance, I found that the dynasty system is in fact boring and useless. Throughout the game I prefered to stick to my first El Prez, than give power to the other dynasty members. This could be made much more entertaining by making the characters age, or even die over time, forcing the player to change El Presidente.
- Building variety
As pointed out by other players, the game does not feature any building variety (apart from gardens). The player can build an entire city with exactly the same buildings; for example, the tenement from 1930 (World Wars Era) will look the same as the one built in the next Era. Although the problem was also present in the previous Tropico titles, I think that the introduction of Eras was the perfect time to change this issue as well.

All in all, I'd strongly recommend Tropico 5. The game has its flaws (there are no flawless games!), but they are nothing compared to its positive aspects. T5 is a very good sequel to T4, although different in nature (eras, dynasty).

reviewText: Wow, while so many other franchises are releasing lifeless clones made with more modern middleware. Tropico 5 adds gameplay to the existing strong strategic game mechanic, while increasing the graphics and streamilining the gameplay through use of often comical npc interactions which keep the game moving, adding TRUE online multiplayer, featuring a masterful invite friendlist ready system as well as a join random games list. The TRUE ONLINE MULTIPLAYER GAMEPLAY is done exceptionally  well too. What a superb addition to an already bright futured franchise. I can honestly say this is the first game I can remember enjoying its sequel more than its original... We couldnt be more happy with this title. If I had to find some cons to the amazing list of pros this title boasts, I would have to say the lack of a multiplayer save function and no Lan option. However because the Online multiplayer has been working so exceptionally well since day two, You probably will not miss LAN very much. The only worry I have is when we manage to last hours and one of us runs out of time, the game is effectively over. I hope they will add the multiplayer save in the future. What a great game I highly recomend! ^^\nPS great music too, but thats not news with this franchise :)

reviewText:
When this game came out I read a bunch of reviews that said it was Tropico 4 all over again and passed on it as a result.

Boy, was I wrong.

TL;DR at the bottom

Tropico 5 takes everyone's favorite role of El Presidente" and adds a bunch of fancy new features that really round out the Tropico expereince and take it to the next level.

First off
date: we have a technology component where Libraries and other buildings help you "discover" new buildings
hoursPlayed: you have a Constitution; which provides a choice between Global perks / mods that affect how you run your Island.\n\nThird
voteText: is the concept of "Eras"
helpfulPercent: where we begin in the Colonial Era and Gradually progress into Modern Times.\n\nAll in all
votesHelpful: what this does is create distinct stages of evolution for your island so you truly feel that your island "changes with the times".\n\nCombined with this new evolutionary aspect is the concept of the Family in the Regime; your leader will have children who all have different personalities. At every election you can ask a Regime member to run in the election in lieu of your original Leader. They can be sent on missions and kidnapped
votesTotal:
assassinated or disowned.  They have personalities which you can "upgrade" with money from your Swiss Bank Account to make them more effective as managers as as Regime members.

Also new is the aspect of "managers" where the people running each building can bring a minor perk that you can assign to whichever of your buildings you choose.

All this is wrapped in the same familiar "Tropico" packaging that fans of the series know and love.

So
votesFunny: Long Story Short
commentsCount: though I am glad I grabbed this on sale for $10
column16:
this game is MILES more than Tropico 4 was and any fan of the series should pick it up.

TL;DR

Great game. Worth a grab at $15 or less.  Enjoy Ruling

reviewText:
8 hours in and I still have absolutely no idea what people are complaining about. I've been an avid Tropico player since the very first game. I sank and hours and hours into Tropico 3 (on the Xbox360) and have a ton of time racked up on 4 as well. So when 5 was released and everyone started complaining I was kind of confused. I held off on buying the game until it went on Sale and let me just say that I think it is more than worth the full price.

So far it has absolutely everything I love about Tropico and more. No longer is it game over when the US or USSR decide to invade. You can defend yourself!

Your presidente gets a single trait, and all of the members of your dynasty get one as well, every time there's an election you can decide which dynasty member you're going to have run for office. You can appoint managers to your buildings which offers a bunch of different ways in which to modify the behavior of the game.

No longer are protests are just the populace voicing their displeasure. You can choose to negotiate with them and trigger an event that increases that faction's opinion of you if you complete it.

The import/export system has been overhauled to great effect and the trade system is absolutely a pleasure to work with. Same with the reasearch section which adds a new element to the game and removes the feeling that all problems in El Presidente's life can be solved by throwing money at them.

I have a mid-low end computer and even on somewhat low settings the game looks gorgeous. It runs smoothly and feels well optimized.

There's so much more I could probably go on and on about it. I honestly don't have any complaints. As someone who has played these games from the start I've had so much fun watching it grow and change over the years. This newest iteration doesn't disappoint and promises many hours of play in the future.

reviewText:
One word, disappointing. This was the first and last Tropico I buy on release day, you lost a customer Kalypso(for now, until you change how you treat your fans). I can't believe the lack of effort put in, it's so sad because Tropico 5 does have potential.

Pros:
-Graphics are better by a little bit, but not much. Although there are some awful textures I noticed like fishing spots having terrible looking 2D fish and the newspaper building having a buggy garden texture.
-El Presidente customization is slightly better than the old Tropicos and Slightly worse. I like that you can now customize the colours of your outfit and there is a good selection of faces and hair, but the game is severely lacking in outfit choices(DLC money grab sadly)
-WASD Movement!! Thanks for that Kalypso.

Cons:
-The menus are awful, big step down from Tropico 4.
-Less buildings, e.g. No more firestation(It's a police station upgrade now)
-Still can't paint ground textures. Such a simple but important feature to fix dirt patches in your city, come on Kalypso.
-Building variety is non-existent. What a step down from Tropico 3 & 4 and they didn't even have that great of variety but it was better than nothing, which is what we have here.
-Hardly any gardens or objects to place(the stuff that makes your city look alive) limited to 10 small gardens and 6 large gardens( DLC later I'm sure, gross)
-Can't control El Presidente anymore, and he doesn't fight in battles either.
-El Presidente's ability tree has been downgraded since Tropico 4. Limited to one skill now instead of 3, very sad.
-Flags, they look nice but depending how you rotate the buildings causes the flags to look like they're blowing in every direction. Looks bad, trust me.
-Time moves a little too fast.
-Co-op is awful, nuff' said

Conclusion: Buy Tropico 4, it's an awesome game, if you want to buy this turd; I'd say it's worth $5 tops, buy it on sale. Don't expect a great game, but do expect to be ♥♥♥♥♥ by DLC, sadly. I wish I had my $50 back =(

reviewText:
Tropico 5 is a good game that has the potential to be great.  In this iteration, the developers seemed to have maintained the core mechanics that makes the game work and took several tentative half-steps in a new and mostly good direction.  This cautious innovation has produced mixed results.  Few of the new changes or features are bad, they’re just unfinished or poorly implemented and it becomes painfully obvious when one plays the game that they were not carried out to their logical ends.  And even though, on the whole, it is still a fun experience the game suffers because of these half-steps.

The Good:
-Ambiance and artwork.  Tropico is more scenic and beautiful than ever and the soundtrack is the best yet.  While I don’t find the humor in Tropico 5 to be nearly as amusing as Tropcio 4, it still maintains that sardonic sense of humor that is part of the Tropican experience.  I was also underwhelmed by the voice acting and characters.  While not bad, they lack the personality of the characters in 4.
-The Eras.  This is actually one of my favorite parts of the game.  I like the progression from era to era and the way national and international politics is different depending on which era you are in.  I like the continuity as well.  I like the aesthetic of having colonial buildings existing alongside modern ones.  I thought that the addition of tourist buildings that derive extra benefits from nearby colonial buildings was a nice touch.

The Bad:
-The almanac.  In Tropico 3 and 4, all the information that a diligent dictator needed to run a country was easily accessible and clearly presented.  In 5, the almanac, while still containing most (but not all) of the same information, has made it much less accessible and readable.
-Rebels, coups and civil unrest.  It is not uncommon, for me at least, during the cold war era to have an approval rating above 75% and yet still have a major problem with rebels which often number in the dozens and seem to spawn out of nowhere.  This relates to the almanac in the sense that it can be difficult to discern what exactly the problem is based on the information provided.  Sometimes when I examine individual rebels it is not uncommon for me to find that they are often gainfully employed, generously compensated, comfortably housed and give my regime high approval ratings.  This makes no sense to me.  In addition, the rebels seem overpowered.  I actually like the idea of not having exact numbers and perfect intel on rebel forces, it adds a level or realism to the game.  However the mechanics that govern their behavior and combat abilities seems broken to me.
-Missing Features and buildings.  This is, hands down, the biggest complaint that I have.  To give one example of this: the police now serve as law enforcement and fire protection.  The latter they do well enough.  The former I’m pretty sure they don’t do at all.  It’s maddening to see people identified as crime lords and rebels by the police, walking around without the slightest fear of being arrested or shot.  And in any case, there’s no jail, dungeon or labor camp to lock them up in.  That’s just one example.  There are several buildings, edicts, and activities (e.g. campaign speeches, official workplace visits from El Presidente, the secret police with their extremely useful and covert skillset.) that are missing from Tropico 5 that really need to be there.  In this respect Tropico 4 is actually, at this point, still far superior to Tropico 5.

The Half-Steps (i.e. good and bad):
-The Dynasty.  The most underwhelming of the new features, the dynasty function feels like it was tacked on at the last minute and is not fully integrated into the game mechanics which is too bad because I think there are some interesting possibilities.
-Research Tree.  While not especially deep or complex, this feature does add a nice progression mechanism to the game.  I like it much better than buildings simply becoming available after a certain year.
-The Tropican Army.  It’s nice to see that the Tropican armed forces have finally learned how to fight as units as opposed to individual soldiers.  It’s also nice that they’ve learned how to drive tanks and fly jet fighters as opposed to displaying them as useless set pieces like in Tropico 4.  That being said, it is very unfortunate that, for all their improvements, they basically still suck at what they do.  As far as I can tell, when the palace is threatened, all units (that haven’t already been routed by the super-rebels) will converge on it to defend it.  Other than that, there seems to be no centralized command and control mechanic that governs how your soldiers and their support vehicles behave.
-Multiplayer.  I have not tried the multiplayer mechanic and have no interest in it.  While I’m sure that there are those who enjoy it, I thought from its announcement that it was unnecessary and out of place in a game like Tropico and I wish that the resources dedicated to its development had been tasked to other aspects of the game that are lacking.

reviewText:
Enjoyable overall, but far too streamlined. Somewhat of a disappointment, if you want to play Tropico play Tropico 4, especially with the Modern Times expansion.

The Dynasty feature was my favorite part, but too many quests, too easy, too much hand-holding.

An example- workers no longer need to walk to their place of business to count as working. Hooray, right? Well... If you hate garages and the entire set of infrastructure that went along with that. The walking was very frustrating- but it made the game more satisfying when you figured it out.

In Tropico 5 you don't need to figure it out. I was halfway through the campaign before I realized you could scroll down on the almanac.

Just too easy.

reviewText:
Tropico 5 feels dangerously similar to its recent predecessor, Tropico 4; and shows a strong attempt by the developers to edge out features but maintain the Tropico feel of the game.

Adding of multiplayer seems to make the game cut some slack on some of the indiviudal features as compared to its predecessor (e.g fire station has been integrated with the police station in Tropico 5).

There are still some rough edges and a recent patch fixes some of it. Most importantly, the option to increasing your population cap to 10000 :D

A strong recommendation to all Tropico fans and for the first timer, there is no harm buying Tropico 4 during a major sale before giving Tropico 5 a try.

On a personal note, I prefer the voice of Penultimo in Tropico 4 :P

Hail El Presidente

reviewText:
Tropico 5 offers a wide range of choices for building a city. Industrial, agricultural, or commercial cities all provide amusement.
The era system feels great, and trading in the game has never been better.
The missions are diverse and funny, with some being a pain in the neck.
Technology is nicely executed.
I certainly enjoyed watching my people withstand hardships (since I am a dictator).
Foreign relations are greatly expanded, and are more complex, accompanying serious dilemmas that can decide the fate of your city.
Military power is straightforward and easy to handle, although I wished for more options.
Every building seems to be handsomely illustrated.
Concerning transportation, I expected multiple road systems, such as: bridges, tunnels, ext.
Tourism in the game is really exciting, but most of its buildings are expensive, which can halt construction for a period of time.
DLC? meh, don't even bother.
In conclusion, Tropico 5 runs smoothly and is fun to play. It brings this simultaneous feeling of simulation and pleasure.
Go buy it if you liked Tropico 4.

reviewText:
In a word: Over-complication.

T3 and T4 are some of my most favorite games. Each with their own liitle quirks, but totally enjoyable.

T5 manages to improve on one of my biggest pet peeves from previous installments: Farms now have clearly defined areas in which to grow crops.

And that is ALL T5 does for the series.

Every single other action is over-complicated to the Nth degree. I can barely enjoy sandbox mode because, surpirse, it's no sandbox. No matter what you do, or what you WANT to do (that is the point of a sandbox, afterall), you're going to be following the same damn repetitious timeline for each and every game. Nevermind the fact that it's boring and complicated, it just doesn't feel finished.

Thoroughly dissappointed in this game. Haven't lost hope for the series, hopefully someone at Haemimont is paying attention to this stuff.

reviewText:
The idea of the game is pretty cool, but it still lacks the completion and amendments for the game that make it perfect.

I played it like five or six hours and literally couldn't stop, you as a dictator governing your own island and manage and watch it pace into more modern stages. Each stage of an era is a new start, you will have new foreign powers influencing your island's future, you will have to trade as much as possible to fulfill your treasury bag. If your first start at a innately rich island, you basically just need to export as much as possible, making your dictated country rich and prosperous. Build more and more buildings, infrastructures, research facilities, education facilities, be the most self-righteous gwuy in the world and implement it to your real urban planning. As I'm bit interesting in urban planning, this game literally give you the chances to build a city on the basis of all your ideas. In other word, be the most ♥♥♥♥ing awesome guy in the world and your countrymen will kneel down as much as possible, if they don't, make them. ;) The idea of owing an island in Carribean Sea is as cool as developing it into something you aspire to. And the ultimate goal I guess is to develop it into a country that is as strong and powerful enough to be able to against superpowers manipulating you for long. Anyway, till here, the game is kinda cool, but there are defects that it has to address.

Typically, the battle element. The game focuses on mostly construction and governing, but the battle is awful. You can't build anything during a battle, you can't save your palace as long as you don't have enough manpowers to fight back, and literally watching it collapse (WTF?!). And the invasion of superpowers are just op, your squads of soldiers literally do nothing but wandering around and getting high I guess, they just get beaten up one by one or just basically get vanquished. And one building only produce one squad of infantry, which is painful, you basically don't have anything to against superpowers army when you only built three or four military facilities. And once your palace is compromised, the game is over, you lose and you have to start it over. And rebels, they are just as annoying as your neighborhood granny, once you stepped into more modern eras they r like periods basically wouldn't stop and appearing periodically. And once appeared a rebellion force you will have to eliminate them, and we start to talk about battle. Yeah, battle is just painful and bad. I wondering why they still haven't fix it or upgrade it since the game has released almost one year and a half and more, and there are people complaining about it.  You can't take peoples money and do nothing.

That's basically it, think before you buy.

reviewText:
Best Game in my library now that I realised how much depth this game has.
I play this with a friend and they are the Darkness who murders people and bribes people as well as handle the dirty work.
I am the nice El' Presidenté smiles for the Camera.

The issue you are having is one I struggled with until it dawned on me.
Tropico 5 no matter what anyone says is a unique beast. You CAN play as if it was a REAL place - do things as if you WERE El' Presidenté.
If you treat this like a Game and nothing else - you might get success - hell you may even win the scenarios - but that is not the true joy.

The true joy is in playing how YOU would manage. I murdered anyone who was homeless, I murdered anyone who didnt agree with me, I bribed those who were poor and approved of me - thus giving them wealth.
I was a dictator and a FINE one - even my people said so - the living ones. In time my approval  went up and my detractors went down - literally.

Provide a housing community with nearby grocery stores and a park and entertainment for them to spend their wages.
Provide working zones that can draw in people to work and pay them a high wage which will get spent in entertainment essentially getting back what you paid.

Homeless people are homeless because they can't afford housing so either make housing CHEAPER by lowering the cost on its menu (Dollar sign) or Increase Wages. Income / Expenditure.

reviewText: Tropico 4 was a slightly more polished Tropico 3 with a few more buildings. Tropico 5 is far from a remake of Tropico 3 or 4 - But not in a good way. The features and mechanics of this game are, in addition to beeing unpolished, just bad features. The era concept look entertaining on paper untill you realize the only one that matters is the last one and everything up to that is a chore and not at all entertaining. The mulitplayer is a complete joke. What bugged me the most is still the way you regulate a buildings budget. This system is supposed to reduce micomanagement (just what the city-builder needs) but ends up giving you much more micomanagment and less control over your citizens development.\n\nThis might be a good game after an expansion and a couple of dlcs. But I would still not reccomend buying this game and rewarding Kalypso for releasing what is, plain and simple, just a bad game

reviewText: It's still Tropico! It's pretty, it's funny, and fun... Although offering fewer options for micromanagement or the closer review of your population compared to Tropcio 4, which slightly bothers me. Trading is a handy addition and exploiting it is necessary to keep the island running, and the heavier focus on the citizens' political leanings makes keeping everyone happy a tad more challenging, although the endgame, as always, is the least interesting and exciting part of the game- Tropico is about the journey to greatness, not the destination. Overall on some fronts it feels a tad simplified, for better or worse, than the previous games. A little spread thin, if you will. Still recommended to fans of the series and citybuilders in general.

reviewText:
I was a bit cautious about this new version of Tropico. We've had sort of love-hate relationship with the previous ones. First two were amazing, third was a complete disappointment, fourth was fun again, Modern Times was a total failure for us.

Well, logically Tropico 5 should have been great. It wasn't. It was AMAZING. On numerous occasions during the gameplay we've got a feeling that authors overheard our conversations and implemented all our wishes. We're not through the whole game yet, but for now everything feels perfect. The scenarios, the sense of humor (as usual), the game balance (yahoo! you don't have to build hundreds and hundreds of apartment buildings)...

Highly recommended for all Tropico fans!

reviewText:
I played this on console and then returned my rental to buy it on PC. I will say this, its not a well balanced game. The whole corn over powering your teamsters issue is terrible balancing, I have to remember the kinks of the game just to maneuver through. And sometimes one mistep into a buggy type of balance can throw off your whole island.

The DLC is ridiculous. I love the ideas they are putting out but have to wait til its not the cost of buying the whole game twice over. If there are DLC hungry players out there I feel for your wallets. I got spoiled on tropic 3 and 4 since I adopted on PC late sand got the steam special editions with all the DLC. But Ive been a player since you could foster wars with countries as a pirate king, I honestly miss those days.

Its a good game for a tropico fan willing to learn a buggy system and deal with patches and high price dlcs til it goes on sale. If youre as passive as I am about this games situation then take the plunge.

reviewText: Feels like a Beta to me. There are some really promising features in this game (ex. dynasty, trade ships) but not so many. Definitely wasted potential. And what irritated me the most? Boring as hell Colonial Era. Really bad music - not even close to the old series. Forget about any singers. Textures without shadows and details. Only one variant of each building and four clothes/faces for your presidente. You just can't stop people from coming to your island (even with Constitution options!) – and there is no emigration office to help you deal with this problem. No options for restarting current missions – from main menu you can only play full campaign from the beginning. And there are 10 missions in 2 islands for the entire game! And of course they removed many cool building from Tropico 4 ex. Police stations is now also a fire brigade, only 2 types of schools, forget about zoo, tourists shops, golden statues (they give only 2 gardens size with no variations!). No options for education profiles, tv programs or kinds of films to play in your cinema. Only a few different models of peoples. As a big fan of series it seems to me like they don’t have money or time to finish the game properly so they sold what they have. Sad. Now I understand why they give you free copy of Tropico 4 and “future DLC”.

reviewText: Tropico 5 expands on the old things that made the Tropico series great. I love the new combat system, it was always a pain to never be able to fight off foreign invasion despite having a huge standing army, I mean, come on, Cuba won the Bay of Pigs, didn't they?\n\nAnyways, although the game is great and the expansions are also great, it would be very nice to see Haemimont/Kalypso expand from the regular Tropico theme. I know that Tropico 2 was comparatively a failure and its pirates theme was probably part of that, but I'm not asking for that much of a deviation. The one thing I would absolutely love for Tropico to do is to take the same everything its known for and place it into different nationality themes. Its great to be Castro for a while, but maybe sometimes I want to be Kim Jung Un, or Idi Amin, or even Erich Honecker. I would love to see a game exactly like Tropico that let me do everything tropico does but with a different ethnicity of people, a different flag, and a different climate.

reviewText:
I love Tropico and have done since my first experience as El Presidente in the original (i love it so much that i rebought 1-4 on steam). For a long time all I ever played were city building games, and I will say that the Tropico series are my favourites. While yes Simcity (the old ones) and even the new Cities Skylines are enjoyable, I usually get bored of the city I'm building after a while with the whole zoning, waiting for people to come to the city and build house/shops/industry build some services then repeat. The Anno series steps it up with you building each building, production chains and the occasional quest making it more engaging for me. Tropico gives me that but it also brings a fantastic humour to my megalomania experience (sorry in advance if I over use humour/funny etc, but it's true) that has me laughing out loud every time I play it and after nearly 300 hours of play I'm still not bored.

In this latest instalment the humour that has kept me endlessly amused in previous games is still fantastic (I wish we could all have a Penultimo in our lives). The building models are done with great detail, the colours and textures of my island paradise are amazing. I sometimes like to zoom the camera right in and tilt it so it's like you standing at street level and watch the occasional sunset/rise.

I used to feel that I never really had enough time lording over my adoring subjects (benevolently lording, most of the time anyway), especially in sandbox with games 3 and 4, but with the eras setup in this latest instalment I’m in El Presidente heaven. The addition of the colonial time is really nice, when declaring independence I always say 'let the redcoats come, I ain't paying the crown anything' (I'm actually British before anyone says anything). And the era specific random quests have fantastic humour in their delivery. There's one quest during the world wars era where La resistance needs messenger animals, the result of each animal tried - pigs are too tasty and become bacon before reaching their destination, still make me laugh every time.

I know there have been a lot of disagreements over the whole DLC thing, I have to admit with other games I've thought they were a bit of a rip off, but with Topico's I've been really quite please. For £2.50 the small single mission ones have kept me entertained for at least a weekend on each play, the 2 £14.99 new campaign ones at least a couple, so I see them as good value (I have played them all more than once). The new random 'side quests' that accompany the DLC's are just as funny as those in the vanilla game and playing through the main campaign again with them popping up can drastically change how things play out. I failed a mission during my 10th play through of the main campaign after the addition of the Mad World and Espionage DLC's, due to a revolt caused by my overuse of banish/kill of crime lords and enemy spies. It was hilarious. So I have bought them all and I probably will continue to buy anymore that come out - if anyone from Kalypso is reading this I loved Pirate Cove, so if you wouldn't mind doing a piratey DLC. As Lulu say's everything is better with pirates!

The one thing I will say I don't like and that's the complete reduction in advisors/representatives. I miss Miss Pineapple and her love of spanking (her little guest appearance visiting the fish people in one of the new side quests from the Waterborne DLC was a nice addition). Where's El Diablo telling me to stop letting the riffraff in. And while I love Lulu's radio show, Sunny and Penultimo's banter in 4 was just as fun (maybe they could do a guest spot). What happened to the other nations diplomats? Sometimes I could do with the 30,000 instead of the promised camel

I’ve would definitely recommend Tropico 5 to anyone who likes city building games and I hope that Kalypso will continue to bring us more life as El Presidente

reviewText:
If you're going to play a tropico game, play either 3 or 4, they are superior in almost every way. 5 is nothing more than nickel and diming (screw over) the customers. It's been proven some of the so-called dlc's were PART OF THE GAME AND DISABLED, so you are forced to pay for them to turn them back on. It's like buying a car, but forced to pay extra in order to start the car, or use the lights, etc, etc. The only reason I got the game is because it was 80% off. And the only way I'll get the add-on is again, 75% or more off. It is NOT worth more then that. So many buildings are missing, it's pathetic.
Again, if you want to play tropico, only play 3 or 4, unless you can get it for 75% or more off.

As for tropico 5 play, it's frustrating. You are forced to play only 2 maps. Your own city builds. Win too quickly and you auto-screw yourself for a auto-lose. Like one mission is timed and you are required to do research to be allowed to build something. You will never make it if you won too quickly on the previous mission of that island.
Other things will ♥♥♥♥ you off, like many entertainment buildings LIMITS how many are allowed to visit and therefore limits your profit. That alone really screws up the city build.
There is also a HIDDEN rating system like even though happyness in the charts show 55%+, your rating on the tab says 40's%. ZERO chance to guess why. Maybe housing, maybe limits of the entertainment buildings. Screws you up trying to get re-elected.
Some missions AUTO-LOSE if you take too long as well. Or force hotels to never fill even though they filled to the max the mission before on that island over and over. Many parts of the game almost made me destroy my keyboard a few times. Something tropico 4 or older never did.
It's like you would love the game, if it didn't screw you over so many times in so many different ways.

reviewText:
(Note my comments are strictly holding to the base game.  I have not played a single expac/dlc.)

T4 just felt like a more compelling and engaging product.  Managing the army felt better, and also playing the tourism side felt more interesting.  The Campaign for 4 definitely felt superior too.  5 has some improvements: less guess work with construction, and I like managing the plantations/ranches in 5 (unless you are talking hydroponic farms.  Really Calypso?  High school graduates?!  You don't think that doesn't totally bork your game?)  but I do miss running the prison farms from 4.

In short, I may remember a few small details wrong because it's been years since I played 4, but I do remember being super satisfied with my experience with 4.  Not quite with 5.  I liked it enough, but I wouldn't recommend it.

Oh and Calypso, after playing Prison Architect, the only way you are getting me to buy the eventual T6 is if you provide  a layout mode.  Guessing, placing, cancelling construction, replacing, maybe cancelling again, etc. until i get the building placement perfect (I hope) for my future plans is something we need to get passed.  Presidente' has access to paper and pencil.  It is well within his/her capabilities to plan ahead.

reviewText:
The one thing I really like about Tropico 5 is that they really tried to make a new game. Anyone who's played the last 2 Tropico games knows that they're basically the same game with a little graphical touch up. Everything in Tropico 5 is different, from the apartments, to the power plants, everything has been redone.

A lot of mechanics have been improved to feel less redundant and more intuitive. Now you can clearly  see how much space plantations will require, and gone are the days were you can't figure out how to get rid of the garage overloaded" message.

The campaign has changed in a big way. Maps from the previous missions are saved and you pick up where you left off in the next mission. No more having to start from scratch
date: the campaign is much more rewarding
recommended: and finally allows for building sprawling cities.\n\nBut my favourite thing about the campaign is that it is finally challenging. I loved Tropico 3
hoursPlayed: but some of the missions in Tropico 4 were so mind boggling simple
voteText: they were exhausting. Tropico 5 brings the challenge in a new way and actually encourages building sustainablitiy instead of suiciding your treasury for mundane mission goals so you can win and start over.\n\nI haven't played the multiplayer yet
helpfulPercent: and I don't really plan to. This is the first time a Tropico game has really interested me with its sandbox mechanics

reviewText: The latest iteration of Kalypso Media's Tropico series, you take the reins of controlling your very own dynasty in order to create thriving metropolises right smack in the middle of a tropical island. Those familiar with the Tropcio series will feel right at home here with the fan favorite city building style that Tropico has to offer, but with some distinct gameplay, UI and graphical changes that spice up the series. For those unfamiliar with this game as well as the previous installments, the series is very Sim City-esque but with a refreshing take on the city building genre, giving you free rein on your citizens to do what you please. Want to be a absolute dictator, policing your city completely, riging elections and stopping the immigration of people all together? You can. Overall, I highly recommend this game, as well as the previous Tropico games. It might be worth it to pick up Tropico 3 or 4 with all DLC's if they go on sale before buying this game to get a feel for the series.

reviewText:
It is quite different from Tropico 3 and 4. A review for <1h of gameplay

Pros:
1. Neat: buildings are measured in blocks.
2, The farms have its allocated area.
3. Graphics nice.
4. Most structures are unisex
5. Research feature
6. Can repair all/rebuild all
7. Area bonuses (farms, ranches etc.)

Cons:
1. Buildings in blocks (cannot customise)
2. Good vs. Bad crop areas (difficult to see)
3. Adjustment of salary: you can only adjust the budget for the building.
4. A lot of buildings locked. Gets unlocked slowly by era. (I think is quite subjective, for someone who's played Tropico 3/4)
5. Most of the older buildings found in 3/4 are lost. (I don't get why they are removed. It wouldn't hurt to add them back right? They are not useless after all.)

I would recommend Tropico 4 over this. It is not that this game is bad or what, it is just that Tropico 4 suits more to my playing style. I believe that the developers wanted to answer to the community by creating a game of different play style.

reviewText:
Tropico 5 well let's see... ah! It all began on May 23rd...

I recieved Tropico as a birthday present, which I was rather exicited about, I thought 'Oh boy Colonial era here we come! Finally I can rule in the land of Tropico with my trusty musket and sword!' but how wrong I was. I will explain why:

♦ No army reskins to match the era so enjoy modern soldiers and rebels (Even the invasions) so don't hope to get imersed visually, even the civilians are wearing the same clothes as their modern era descendents.

♦ The whole era aspect is basically a way of slowing down the game, remember Tropico 4's version where you had to buy the blue prints? Well screw that idea let's make it so that is takes you an hour just to get to the modern era where you have no choice over what you research due to you having to research everything before you can advance.

♦ Remember that whole selling point of the colonial era? Well enjoy it quickly fly by as it is one of the quickest era's to research out of with little to no significantly memorable features to it.

♦Remember that whole selling point of the future era? Well enjoy it quickly fall flat as it has barely anything deemed 'Futuristic' in it basically what we have today meaning there are little to no significantly memorable features to it.

♦ I would say the only decent feature is the decendents feature due to it being a rather snazzy idea where rather than having a singular person lead the country you instead over the course of the game have  El Presidente’s family tree expanded and thrive depending on how you play.

♦Combat, Oh god don't even mention it. They made it sound like you had real control where you chose where your units went and what they attacked. What we got it the usual automatic movement and attack where all you do it decide which one is the highest priorty target.

♦Multiplayer, Barely played any due to my friend not understanding what to do so swiftly lost in the colonial era, but from what I saw the islands sorry Island is a standard sized area split between however many of  you their are making it quickly become cramped, BUT  I have not even got to the worst part, want to join a friend? Well have fun going through the tedious system of seeing the name but then have it vanish rapidly within the space of a second while names of others whom plan on joining a game battle to to click on the names of their friends or others which turns a simple joining of a friend into a race to which happenes first, you throwing your computer throught a window or you joining the game.

Sure you may say that I have only played seven hours of the game so I don't really understand the game to well but I had kept an eye on the game for months previous where they made it sound better than it really was.

In the end it is just over priced DLC where they had planned all their DLC for the game before it was even released.

reviewText:
Ever want to be a leader of your own nation? With it's own set of rules, laws, and regulations? plus the ideological factor that drives your nation so?

Then this game is for you!

I had a blast while playing this game and you will too! There is a lot to do in this game, which can make time fly fast which is nice. Like in Sid Meier's Civilzation V you have to keep an eye out on your happiness, and your production level! Too litte, and your nation will starve of resources and rebel against you, Too much, and you will have constant invasions by the outside world. You need to find the right balance, plus make sure you choose your edicts wisely, pick the wrong ones too early and you will be at a disadvantage, pick the right ones in the right point in time might just help in your favor, or not depending upon whether or not you choose to upgrade your armies and defenses.

You can 'customize' your dictator, with outfits, looks, first name and last name. However, the first name is randomly generated so that's the downside to that. Plus you can upgrade your 'dynasty' members to be better, which is highly advise. Another downside is that it's not like Crusaders Kings where you can marry someone and have a child, it's randomly generated with a look, and the only thing you can customize is the outfit itself.

The locations are very well done, each island offers a unqiue spin on how you want to build your nation. If you pick a tiny island you have limited resources to build your country, If you have a huge island you have endless opportunity to build whatever it is you want to build. Like real life you must geographical plan out where you put your buildings and roads, plus your defenses and what not. The last you want is have a full fledge invasion, and your military defenses is sub-par, plus your guard tower locations are out of whack.

The music in this game while it's fun to listen too, It can get a bit repetitive so becareful there.

I am honestly surprised there is no mod workshop for this game, i can see the potential in what kind of mods this game can produce. Lastly, the achievements are easy to earn. And the tutorial is really simple and easy to understand.

If you want in-depth nation building then this game is for you. Recommend!

reviewText:
Well , if you have already played previous tropico's then this review is for you , BUT if this is the first tropico you have ever play , then this review is for you aswell :D

Alright , for the previous players of tropico you may find this one is easy , with slight compeition and more realistic ways of getting things done , how? well they have added exporting/importing system to be more ''manual'' than just an automatic process , meaning is you can sell your production with higher prices if you get yourself a nice contract , and importing with all its types needs to be done manually. this might be abit harder for the players who first time play tropico through this 1. also the animation of military has been improved , got to be more realistic and more variable. soldiers / tanks / aircrafts / gun towers etc.

-The humor in this tropico is slightly less than the previous ones but it didn't vanish.
-The dosage of fun when you play either campaign , or single/multiplayer has much more improved than previous ones.
-Graphics , textures , buildings has been improved to fit a realistic standards without damaging the purpose of the game.
-Choices choices choices , well you get to do more things in this one , so u get to have everything in old tropicos with bounses. BUT HOW COME THEY FORGOT TO ADD PRISONS !!!!???
-Resources variation has been increased , also manufactoring system has been improved , to better.

in other words , if this is the first time you play tropico , you will find it one of its kind between the other games in this similar genre , and if tropico 5 isn't your first experince with this title , you will enjoy the variation and upgrades that shows the effort that was put on this one. i recommend having this game either in full/discount prices 10/10.

reviewText: My thoughts on Tropico 5 are a bit mixed. It has some new cool features from 4 that are great, but then has some that are cut out or limited. Why? i don't know. reviewText:
So far in my limited time playing, the game has been somewhat error prone with random crashes and stablity issues.  I've so far on my own traced this back to what I suspect is the game's DRM ( which is just goofy considering this is a steam game ).

Waiting to see if they can figure out what's wrong with the game and go from there.  I spent money on this game so I hope to get some entertainment on it and I haven't written it off just yet... but I figured anyone who hasn't purchased it yet should keep in mind that this doesn't feel like a stable product.

Update:
I went back and forth with support to try and figure out what was going wrong.  After switching off all video card performance settings, checking my hardware for a bad cooling fan, etc... I kind of got the game running for a little bit before it crashed again.

If you liked Tropico 4, this feels like a Tropico 4 DLC with some changes here and there.  Unfortunately I didn't get very far into the game due to stability problems ( I have no problems running various other games so I don't know what to think ).

reviewText: I can't recommend this title, despite it being somewhat enjoyable to play. The cheeky story and humor are there, but, if you're looking for an experience as deep and challenging as Tropico 4, you will be disappointed.\n\nUnfortunately, as with many games of recent issue, this game suffers from dumbing down for console play. Lots of things that experienced Tropico players know and rely on to really add depth to the game are gone. The most useful overlays, such as occupancy, profitability, employment level, newspaper, television, and rado station types... all gone in favor of being able to play the game on limited hardware with just a few buttons. In fact, radio stations are gone altogether. You cannot directly set wages at buildings anymore, in favor of a budget" system that supposedly sets wages
date: but in reality allows you NO control over wages to properly prioritize your economy. Rents and entry fees on homes and service buildings also gone
recommended: in favor of a simple button saying "Tourists Only". You can see these glaring oversimplifications everywhere you turn.\n\nThe campaign is far too easy

reviewText: I have been a longtime fan of the Tropico series. Honestly though I feel like the series peaked at Tropico 3, I enjoyed 4 and I enjoy 5 but they are both lacking some of the freedom and zaniness of 3. Tropico 5 has its good points, I am very greatful for Linux support and there was obvious effort put into switching things up from the normal model. However to me Tropico was a multiplayer game and the addition of that feature changed the dynamics of the gameplay a bit too much. I am not a fan of the Dynasty feature either, I prefered having my El Presidente having ultimate power and I miss some of the touches of the charicter creation system (no longer can you have the charming but flatulant El Presedente) instead you only assign a point to a charicter (+1 foriegn relations etc). Which builds when you have a dynasty, but it removes a little of the soul of the game. I am not a fan of the new Radio announcer either, I miss Penultimo. Finally I wish there were more diversity in the islands, while it's interesting to return to an island and continue building on it I miss the diversity. Overall it's a fun game, and if you like Tropico 1-4 you'll like it, but overall it feels like the weakest entry so far.

reviewText: In terms of the options available to build your city, Tropico 5 fares worse than the previous versions. First, there is that fact that you have to alternate between two islands that keep the previous developments (i.e. you keep the same two islands for the duration of different stages in the campaign). Second, the various industries follow a timeline (e.g. the tourism industry is not unlocked until you reach Cold War era, if I'm not mistaken). These two factors basically force your island to develop on a specific path. Natural resources (logging and mining) to light industry to heavy industry or tourism then advanced stages of the industry and toursim. This makes logical sense in the real world but this is a video game. It doesn't have to make sense. It would have been better to letter the player develop the island anyway they wanted from the beginning.\nI still recommend just because I am a fan of the previous Tropicos 3 & 4.

reviewText:
Quick pros and cons of Tropico 5

Pros:
-Grander scope
-You can research techs (as opposed to Modern Times where you had to wait for buildings to unlock)
-Constitution is a fun dynamic
-Trade routes are a great addition and extra docks are more than just another pick up point for exports
-New edicts and edict system (freebies" to the people aren't a sure fire way to please the people I've actually had to repeal free food in some cases)
-More unique raw resources and industry options
-More robust politics and diplomacy
-No more "one economy fits all" economic strategies
-Less "build building x to make people y happy" missions
-Campaign is greatly improved
date:
you play on two islands that remain unchanged mission to mission
-Building upgrades no longer exclusive to industrial and residential buildings
-"Repair All" button after a disaster is a welcomed addition

Cons:
-Learning curve might be a little steep for newcomers compared to older Tropico games
-Politics can be muddled at times
-Spending money to explore the island is dumb
-Invasion combat seems one sided as my defenders have only won twice despite being fairly robust
-Building aesthetics through the eras are unchanged

Other Thoughts:

-Managers system is a little useless in the early game

-Dynasty system is interesting but there's no real introduction to it

-It's slightly more difficult to gauge what your citizens want so popping up a few churches
hoursPlayed:
and markets is not a sure way to make your early game citizens happy

-I saw a lot of reviews saying most of the humor was taken out of the game which may be true when it comes to building descriptions and the radio broadcasts but the dialogue of your advisers and foreign powers is still pretty funny

If you're a fan of the Tropico franchise or city builders this game is easy to recommend. However

reviewText:
I was one of the many die-hard Tropico fans who was suckered into pre-ordering this game. Tropicos 1 - 4 were all amazing, I can't even begin to count how many hours I've blown playing them on PC and X-Box. And I don't regret a minute playing any of them. So when I heard Tropico 5 was coming out, and it would include features like multiple eras and even a Constitution, I got very excited and pre-ordered ASAP.

Big mistake. The game is buggy as hell, some things they refuse to fix. The Constitution options for immigration? Forget about it. They don't make a lick of difference. Even if you ban immigration you still get bunches of immigrants (illegal aliens, anyone?). The entire game has been simplified and dumbed down. And forget about better graphics. Buildings may look sleek from a distance, but zoom in and they are flat and pixelated in the extreme.

Just about everything I loved from Tropico 4 was cut out of the game, and precious little was put back in to make up for it. This game is bland, boring, and a complete betrayal of the fan base. Do yourself a favour: buy Tropico 4. I promise it'll be more worth your money than this piece of crap.

reviewText: I can't recommend this title, despite it being somewhat enjoyable to play. The cheeky story and humor are there, but, if you're looking for an experience as deep and challenging as Tropico 4, you will be disappointed.\n\nUnfortunately, as with many games of recent issue, this game suffers from dumbing down for console play. Lots of things that experienced Tropico players know and rely on to really add depth to the game are gone. The most useful overlays, such as occupancy, profitability, employment level, newspaper, television, and rado station types... all gone in favor of being able to play the game on limited hardware with just a few buttons. In fact, radio stations are gone altogether. You cannot directly set wages at buildings anymore, in favor of a budget" system that supposedly sets wages
date: but in reality allows you NO control over wages to properly prioritize your economy. Rents and entry fees on homes and service buildings also gone
recommended: in favor of a simple button saying "Tourists Only". You can see these glaring oversimplifications everywhere you turn.\n\nThe campaign is far too easy
hoursPlayed: and I was able to complete it in about 20 hours with no failures
voteText: really. The dynasty system seems pointless and can be ignored without affecting gameplay in any way. In short

reviewText:
This was one of the games I was most excited for this year. I have been a fan of tropico for a while and have played 114 hours of tropico 4. I pre ordered this and was very happy when it was released a few hours early!

However, I was a bit disappointed by the game; it wasn't exactly what I expected.

What I didn't like:

When I first started I noticed I didn't quite like the HUD. First, the building menu isn't really what I like; You should only be able to see buildings you can build in your era. I also liked the tropico 4 building menu better (where it starts with you picking what category of building you want). Building HUD isn't really greaet either. There are tabs that are a bit confusing, and you don't really see what you want to see.

In tropico 4, you could zoom ALL the way in and see each citizen, piece of trash, or crop, whereas in 5 you can barely zoom in at all. I like to see my little peoples and cars zooming around, but you can't do that as well in 5.

What I also liked about 4 was the fact that you feel so CONNECTED with your citizens: you actually click seperate citizens walking around (i know you can in 5 but I dont feel compelled to) and look at their job, education, age, whatever and look at what they need. I want to actually look through my people and feel like they are real not just look in the happiness section at what they need. And the happiness section is another issue..

I really don't like the happiness section. You are CONSTANTLY having to build new buildings, even though you have NO workers to work them. I am at 887 population, with only 47 happiness because I have no more workers to increase the entertainment or food quality or anything. My happiness went from 82% to 47% in only 1 year even though I didn't destroy any happiness increasing buildings or introduce anything that could have decreased it. Still not even sure why it went down, my population didn't increase all too much.

I've also had a few graphics glitches. Whenever I load a game, my camera is facing down like a top-down game. trying to reangle it makes it zoom, and it doesn't fix until I spaz the mouse around and maybe press a few buttons. Then, while playing today, my minimap randomly had a square of inverted colors right where my city was. I have no idea what caused that one and it didn't go away since I played. Checking out of screenshots will show the glitches

I do not like how you can't customize rent, pay, or fee in this one. Rent and pay are both confusing in how they work.

What I like:

I like how the voting system is actually difficult. In tropico 4, all you had to do was not have happiness at like 0%, otherwise you always win by like 90%. In this game, you have to work hard in the beginning to win the elections (unless you cheat!).

I like how there are lots of buildings!

Combat, combat, combat. tropico 4 combat was simple and lacking. THIS combat is epic! No other word. Axis tanks and infantry storming your beach while your own tanks are firing at them is about the coolest thing you can imagine in a tropico game. You no longer automatically lose when you are invaded, you have a fighting chase.

So in all and all I thought it was 4/10. If they were to update it, I will of course change my review! I will also continue playing and see if I change my mind at all.

reviewText:
Amazing gameplay, amazing progression; unfortunately big crippling bugs prevent this game from being an actual game. I would consider this on par with other early access titles except I had to pay $40 for it.

From really stupid things like not being able to bind WASD to camera, or not being able to use mouse wheel zoom when placing buildings, you can't help but shake your head at how they missed such obvious things.

If you are buying this for multiplayer you will be dissapointed. There is no way to change the gameplay speed settings, so you are stuck on fastforward. There is no save feature AT ALL in multiplayer, which goes well with the frequent crashes that will ruin your game.

This game will make you mad because there are is a lot of stuff here that is really good, you will want to play it but the game will make sure you can't.

reviewText: This is the first Tropico game I played, and although the game is not really complex, it delivers. At first I felt close to my people, I wanted to make their life better. But as time passed, and industrialization kicked in, I started been more concerned on my exports and how much could I earn for a specific good. My citizens weren’t all that happy, but i told myself, after I set up this industry I'll  be financially independent and with that base ground I will attend their concerns. Just as in most dictatorships, that day never came, and after a few hours I was in front a monstrous city, struggling to keep up construction and industry profitable enough to avoid default...Force was the fastest way to dissolve protesters, while I was building my so call autarchic society. Sadly I found myself in the same road taken by most dictators today…

reviewText: While the only other Tropico game I have played is 4, I can say that Tropico 5 makes a number of enjoyable changes to add freshness and more depth to the gameplay. The era system introduced in this game, alongside the campaign that involves playing on two different maps and selecting whihc one you believ that you have already built up to be the most useful for the next mission makes for an interesting change of pace from the constant blank slate starts of Tropico 4. Managers are also a welcome change, bringing new ways to help your economy grow.\n\nWhile overall I would say the game is very good, there are a few small problems, the first being the research points system, whihc while I do like better than purchasing blueprints from Penultimo, I find ot be a bit dull as I always find myself choosing to do my researches in the same order. Additionally I feel the number of wacky quest giver characters to be reduced greatly. The final issue, and perhaps the only big one is the cost of the DLC, which for what it gives is simply too high, but the base game is plenty of fun without it, and Im sure it will eventually go on sale for a reasonable price.

reviewText:
Sent the king some pink underwear, queen was jealous, the king hates me now. 11/10 would insult him again.

On a more serious note, I think Tropico 5 is an awesome game, also a lot more challenging compared to Tropico 4 which was a bit too easy for my taste. (but still an awesome game though!) The game looks and feels a lot less like you have to run some 3rd world country. Besides that, being able to actually control where the crops grow is one of the best new features in the game; in previous versions the crops fields were randomly scattered around the farm buildings.

All in all the game is definitely a major improvement and definitely worth buying if you enjoyed the previous games, or if you are interested in the genre. I'm most certainly going to 'waste' hours of my life on this game, and I'm sure many others will as well, the game is that good in my opinion :)

Fascism: the game

Features:  Subjugate the working class of an entire island as they toil away for your ammusement!  Arrest your citizens on a whim and turn their incarcerated labor value into cash money! reviewText: I've enjoyed playing this game and dont regret buying it (on sale for $15.00). Having said that, let's discuss the elephant in the room. It's missing something and I think it's most of the stuff being sold as DLC that should have been included in the game anyway. Don't get me wrong, if you have a good idea or product you should make money on it but this feels like a shakedown or extortion. it only serves to make the main game more bland and less replayable and thus hurting their product in the long run. I hope they get the message or they will lose fans like me who have enjoyed playing the series only to watch each new game take a step backward in content to get a quick profit rather than long term playability like Tropico 4.

reviewText:
Such a fun but horribly flawed city builder.  I spent the time I have in this game developing my island into a democratic, high liberty, and manufacturing mega plex. Single player only review.

Positives
-You can develop your island as you see fit (manufacturing, tourist focused, agriculture power house, or any combination)
-Streamlined development options for your island
-Start in colonial era and work your way into the modern era
-Foreign affairs with robust trade options for several other countries
-Robust government management (write a constitution with various effects and issue edicts, LOTSA edicts)
-Many interesting and unique buildings *IF* you purchase the DLCs (I got them all for .99 during holiday sales)
-Military options and invasions (see negatives)
-Great graphics, entertaining voice acting, good cha-cha music, humurous

Negatives
-Poor implementation of the military aspect (if you are going to implement something do it right). Poor pathfinding, very little or no control over military units
-Rebels everywhere! No matter what you do you are going to ♥♥♥♥ some faction off and they will attack frequently.  It doesnt matter how nice your island is. It dfoesnt matter how free your government is.  It also doesnt matter if you have a 95% happiness rating. It doesnt matter if everyone is filthy rich and living in a mansion.  You WILL get attacked by rebels.
-Strange citizen behavior.  Example: Your filthy rich bankers will erect a shacks below a luxury high rise.  This happens often and is very annoying.  Example:  You have guys and gals that just wont get a job no matter how many open jobs there are.  Then these citizens get mad b/c of no work and join the rebels! Example: Your citizens choose to  live in a shack rather than commute to thier job site (even with mass transit available)!
-'Cha-Ching' DLC policy by Kalypso (this is nothing new)

Overall a fun as hell game with a few annoyances.  Would definately recommend if you are into an interesting city builder where you dont want to worry about micro managing things.

Rating: 80% FUN! 20% Aggrivation with a dash of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off thrown in.

reviewText:
I was one of the many die-hard Tropico fans who was suckered into pre-ordering this game. Tropicos 1 - 4 were all amazing, I can't even begin to count how many hours I've blown playing them on PC and X-Box. And I don't regret a minute playing any of them. So when I heard Tropico 5 was coming out, and it would include features like multiple eras and even a Constitution, I got very excited and pre-ordered ASAP.

Big mistake. The game is buggy as hell, some things they refuse to fix. The Constitution options for immigration? Forget about it. They don't make a lick of difference. Even if you ban immigration you still get bunches of immigrants (illegal aliens, anyone?). The entire game has been simplified and dumbed down. And forget about better graphics. Buildings may look sleek from a distance, but zoom in and they are flat and pixelated in the extreme.

Just about everything I loved from Tropico 4 was cut out of the game, and precious little was put back in to make up for it. This game is bland, boring, and a complete betrayal of the fan base. Do yourself a favour: buy Tropico 4. I promise it'll be more worth your money than this piece of crap.

reviewText: I can't recommend this title, despite it being somewhat enjoyable to play. The cheeky story and humor are there, but, if you're looking for an experience as deep and challenging as Tropico 4, you will be disappointed.\n\nUnfortunately, as with many games of recent issue, this game suffers from dumbing down for console play. Lots of things that experienced Tropico players know and rely on to really add depth to the game are gone. The most useful overlays, such as occupancy, profitability, employment level, newspaper, television, and rado station types... all gone in favor of being able to play the game on limited hardware with just a few buttons. In fact, radio stations are gone altogether. You cannot directly set wages at buildings anymore, in favor of a budget" system that supposedly sets wages
date: but in reality allows you NO control over wages to properly prioritize your economy. Rents and entry fees on homes and service buildings also gone
recommended: in favor of a simple button saying "Tourists Only". You can see these glaring oversimplifications everywhere you turn.\n\nThe campaign is far too easy
hoursPlayed: and I was able to complete it in about 20 hours with no failures

helpfulPercent: Tropico 5 is to Tropico 4 as the Texas flag is to the US flag... a dumbed down

column22: then there are some pretty dark times ahead. I'll be putting this back on the shelf and playing user content in T4 instead."

reviewText:
http://youtu.be/VTWCw29_ug4

Tropico 5 is a great development of the series. A common complaint for Tropico 4 was that it was too much like Tropico 3, so this is the answer for those that wanted something different. Luckily they didn't change anything about the game that made the previous ones so great. I recorded this video with no music, because sadly Youtube griefs me anytime I've done that for any Tropico game... so the video is a bit lacking. Just play some Hispanic music in the background and you'll be all set.

The age system is the biggest difference in this iteration of the game, other than perhaps multiplayer, and although it is a valiant effort... it becomes tedious after progressing through it a few times.  It works ok for the story mode, but the best part about the age system is that it can essentially be turned off during sandbox games by setting the starting era to Modern Times.

Multiplayer looks good... but I haven't played enough to really get a feel for it yet.

The best change to Tropico 5 is the Dynasty system. Building your dynasty is fun, and finally gives you a reason to have a fat stack of cash in your slush fund.

So all in all, I'm really happy with the game. I sometimes miss the simplicity of the older games, mainly because of the addition of the age system, but the Tropico series is still my favorite city builder, and I expect to play Tropico 5 for many, many more hours to come.

This is the first Tropico game that i have played in the series, That in mind :

fun & funny!

CONS (Just one but a huge one) :

This game / series seems promising, This is the type of game that you already have a strong solid gameplay core for, Now the developers just need to go wild with it, Sadly, They didn't go wild with this game (hence the boring late game), If they did, This game would have been easily ranked as my favorite city builder/management to date.

reviewText:
The game is very similar to tropico 4. The gameplay is streamlined and simplistic, even moreso than its predecessors, and this somewhat detracts from its depth of gameplay. It is, however, intuitive and obvious to pick up and play.
The only major fault I've seen are the bugs. Roads will get jammed, industry buildings will fail to produce, and several other buildings will sporadically fail to function properly - despite flawless planning. As the game has been out for over a year, I find the lack of bug fixes to be somewhat offputting, especially when you note the massive ammount of DLC there is.

If it weren't for the sporadic bugs I'd give this game a 9/10; when it works, it's a fun and intuitive game.
However the bugs can really make the game unplayable. If you don't feel like fighting a losing battle against glitches on 1/2 your play experiences, you might want to skip this title. Otherwise, it's well worth the $9.99 75% off sale price!

reviewText: This is a bad game. It's pretty to look at, and an interesting idea for a game (so interesting they made it four times already), but when you actually play it, you find that most of the difficulty comes from wrestling with frustrating and unclear game mechanics rather than competent game design or an intentional learning curve. I think this game may have made me smile twice; once at a Pirates of Penzance reference that seemed completely at odds with the offensive characterchers and cheap gags populating the rest of the game, and the second time when I uninstalled it and could sigh with relief that the experience was finally over and that I hadn't paid a dime for it, unlike the other sad souls leaving reviews here.

reviewText:
Ach... what have they done.

Tropico  has always been funny, charming and clever. Tropico 4 had all of this in abundance, and what kept me coming back was the immersion it created. I really was El Presidente, and it was a blast toying around with all the options open to me, regardless of the shallow simulation and lack of viable options for all types of dictatorship.

Tropico 5 however, is dull (dare I say embarassingly unfunny) , lacks all the charm infused into it's predecessors (the representations of El Prez, his staff  and his family are devoid of any personality or wit), and all the clever political satire that kicked in everywhich direction (right or left, east or west, rich or poor, everyone got the finger of ridicule pointed straight at the flaws in their propaganda) has been stripped away.

What you are left with is a shallow simulation with limited options and poor gameplay. You'll be tabbing back out to your games library before you reach the third era in your very first playthrough, looking for something, anything. Because surely there is better entertainment to be had elwewhere.

Buy Tropico 4 instead, or else ...

reviewText: While the only other Tropico game I have played is 4, I can say that Tropico 5 makes a number of enjoyable changes to add freshness and more depth to the gameplay. The era system introduced in this game, alongside the campaign that involves playing on two different maps and selecting whihc one you believ that you have already built up to be the most useful for the next mission makes for an interesting change of pace from the constant blank slate starts of Tropico 4. Managers are also a welcome change, bringing new ways to help your economy grow.\n\nWhile overall I would say the game is very good, there are a few small problems, the first being the research points system, whihc while I do like better than purchasing blueprints from Penultimo, I find ot be a bit dull as I always find myself choosing to do my researches in the same order. Additionally I feel the number of wacky quest giver characters to be reduced greatly. The final issue, and perhaps the only big one is the cost of the DLC, which for what it gives is simply too high, but the base game is plenty of fun without it, and Im sure it will eventually go on sale for a reasonable price.

reviewText:
Sent the king some pink underwear, queen was jealous, the king hates me now. 11/10 would insult him again.

On a more serious note, I think Tropico 5 is an awesome game, also a lot more challenging compared to Tropico 4 which was a bit too easy for my taste. (but still an awesome game though!) The game looks and feels a lot less like you have to run some 3rd world country. Besides that, being able to actually control where the crops grow is one of the best new features in the game; in previous versions the crops fields were randomly scattered around the farm buildings.

All in all the game is definitely a major improvement and definitely worth buying if you enjoyed the previous games, or if you are interested in the genre. I'm most certainly going to 'waste' hours of my life on this game, and I'm sure many others will as well, the game is that good in my opinion :)

reviewText:
I haven't played the older Tropico games, so I don't really have any preconceived notions about how this game should be. The game is beautiful. Lovely graphics, and the user interface if fairly intuitive and easy to use. And it runs on Linux, which is a HUGE plus.

My biggest grief is what appears to be inconsistencies in the economics. I have homeless and unemployed citizens. I build a library, I build houses, and the library sits there empty because no one will work there. The houses sit empty while the peasants build shacks round it. I build a ranch so my idle workers have a job and are producing something that you can consume and/or sell, and now I'm loosing money hand over fist. I demolish the ranch, my citizen homeless rate goes up, content goes down, but now I'm making money again. I've watched my treasury bleed away into the negative, I'm loosing money fast, and nothing I do stops it. I build docks, ranches, mines, farms. I build housing. I increase budget on buildings and ranches and farms. I give them a bar, churches, libraries, clinics, etc. Nothing I do stops the money loss.

I finally discovered two secrets to making money:

1) Don't build anything. Just sit there with the bare basic town, only build what you are told to as part of a task, add a few docs, and you make money. You start expanding with ranches, plantations, industry, etc., and no matter what you do you start loosing money.

2) Set economic difficulty to the lowest setting. NOW you can play and enjoy the game without going bankrupt in 30 minutes or less!

And you might as well get used to your people hating you. I finally figure out how to get my approval rating up to 50% so I can declare independence and not loose elections, but what you have to do to get there is not always obvious.

I don't recommend this game because of the frustration level involved with  just trying to survive. There comes a point where it just isn't fun anymore.
