reviewText:
http://youtu.be/VTWCw29_ug4

Tropico 5 is a great development of the series. A common complaint for Tropico 4 was that it was too much like Tropico 3, so this is the answer for those that wanted something different. Luckily they didn't change anything about the game that made the previous ones so great. I recorded this video with no music, because sadly Youtube griefs me anytime I've done that for any Tropico game... so the video is a bit lacking. Just play some Hispanic music in the background and you'll be all set.

The age system is the biggest difference in this iteration of the game, other than perhaps multiplayer, and although it is a valiant effort... it becomes tedious after progressing through it a few times.  It works ok for the story mode, but the best part about the age system is that it can essentially be turned off during sandbox games by setting the starting era to Modern Times.

Multiplayer looks good... but I haven't played enough to really get a feel for it yet.

The best change to Tropico 5 is the Dynasty system. Building your dynasty is fun, and finally gives you a reason to have a fat stack of cash in your slush fund.

So all in all, I'm really happy with the game. I sometimes miss the simplicity of the older games, mainly because of the addition of the age system, but the Tropico series is still my favorite city builder, and I expect to play Tropico 5 for many, many more hours to come.

reviewText:
Such a fun but horribly flawed city builder.  I spent the time I have in this game developing my island into a democratic, high liberty, and manufacturing mega plex. Single player only review.

Positives
-You can develop your island as you see fit (manufacturing, tourist focused, agriculture power house, or any combination)
-Streamlined development options for your island
-Start in colonial era and work your way into the modern era
-Foreign affairs with robust trade options for several other countries
-Robust government management (write a constitution with various effects and issue edicts, LOTSA edicts)
-Many interesting and unique buildings *IF* you purchase the DLCs (I got them all for .99 during holiday sales)
-Military options and invasions (see negatives)
-Great graphics, entertaining voice acting, good cha-cha music, humurous

Negatives
-Poor implementation of the military aspect (if you are going to implement something do it right). Poor pathfinding, very little or no control over military units
-Rebels everywhere! No matter what you do you are going to ♥♥♥♥ some faction off and they will attack frequently.  It doesnt matter how nice your island is. It dfoesnt matter how free your government is.  It also doesnt matter if you have a 95% happiness rating. It doesnt matter if everyone is filthy rich and living in a mansion.  You WILL get attacked by rebels.
-Strange citizen behavior.  Example: Your filthy rich bankers will erect a shacks below a luxury high rise.  This happens often and is very annoying.  Example:  You have guys and gals that just wont get a job no matter how many open jobs there are.  Then these citizens get mad b/c of no work and join the rebels! Example: Your citizens choose to  live in a shack rather than commute to thier job site (even with mass transit available)!
-'Cha-Ching' DLC policy by Kalypso (this is nothing new)

Overall a fun as hell game with a few annoyances.  Would definately recommend if you are into an interesting city builder where you dont want to worry about micro managing things.

Rating: 80% FUN! 20% Aggrivation with a dash of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off thrown in.

reviewText: I've enjoyed playing this game and dont regret buying it (on sale for $15.00). Having said that, let's discuss the elephant in the room. It's missing something and I think it's most of the stuff being sold as DLC that should have been included in the game anyway. Don't get me wrong, if you have a good idea or product you should make money on it but this feels like a shakedown or extortion. it only serves to make the main game more bland and less replayable and thus hurting their product in the long run. I hope they get the message or they will lose fans like me who have enjoyed playing the series only to watch each new game take a step backward in content to get a quick profit rather than long term playability like Tropico 4.

reviewText: This is a bad game. It's pretty to look at, and an interesting idea for a game (so interesting they made it four times already), but when you actually play it, you find that most of the difficulty comes from wrestling with frustrating and unclear game mechanics rather than competent game design or an intentional learning curve. I think this game may have made me smile twice; once at a Pirates of Penzance reference that seemed completely at odds with the offensive characterchers and cheap gags populating the rest of the game, and the second time when I uninstalled it and could sigh with relief that the experience was finally over and that I hadn't paid a dime for it, unlike the other sad souls leaving reviews here.

reviewText:
Went ahead and familiarized myself with the tutorial levels to what new has been added to this already excellent game series; and I have to say, Kalypso has outdone themselves. The engine is smooth, AI works more accordingly, changes to buildings such as updgrades and expanded timelines with technology research has made the next piece in the Tropico anthology an obvious gem.
The reactions from foreign powers and consequences against your little island paradise are vast and far reaching. Random events and disasters are far more balanced; and politics and trade are a bit more in depth, giving players a chance to either maximize profit or be able to work up foreign relations through trade.
Most notable in the Tropico game series, is implementing different era's for your island to push through with a new technology tree, allowing one to progress in numerous paths when deciding there tropical paradises fate.

For any looking for an excellent city building simuation, Tropico 5 is worth the price-tag.

Edit: Update on gameplay:
So I get to a population of about 2,500 and things are looking good not only financially but my diplomatic stances with foreign nations were all warm, if not neutral. However there was discontent brewing over the past decade, the nationalists were becoming increasingly vocal and taking up arms in small rebel actions against my regime. I began noticing arresting rebels belonged to a mixture of the nationalists and environmentalists. Years of an open immigration policy, immigrants on almost every boat to port for the past couple years. Then recently I managed to receive 60 Chinese immigrants.

Immediatly rebel action began to scale up with a series of attacks on my cash crop farms, and they were succeeding with every other attack. I chose to put my foot down and lure the rebels numerous times, thinning there ranks and arresting identified rebels. But of course I had many citizens who were very loyal, I met all their desires, the militarists, globalists and capitalists were almost eating out of the palm of my hand.

Well one fine morning I put the finishing touches on putting the last of identified rebels down. Moments later the uprising began. Markers began popping up everywhere as my military scattered to intercept any rebel forces. There were people fighting for my regime, but many more fighting against. I watched as my population counter suddenly dropped by fifty in mere moments. One by one guard towers fell and the mob slowly gathered together in an unstoppable show of force. My fighters bombarding the crowd to no avail, there were to many to stop now.

After a drawn out battle with some few loyal forces I had left who trekked over half the island to my palace were to late as the rebels burned my personal fortress into ashes, three square blocks on fire or bombed out. The revolution was over, it wasn't even sunset yet.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've been waiting for this game to come to Mac since May. I played at least 150 hours of Tropico 4 (Mac App Store version). But I was nervous about this T5 release because of all the bugs and missing features reported by PC gamers.

I got it anyway on sale from Humble Bundle and I'm so happy I did. The developers have been hard at work since May, fixing many bugs, making gameplay smoother, and creating this wonderful Mac version. The graphics are amazing, especially compared to T4. The buildings and decorations are beautiful. Optimizing buildings with upgrades, budget, and managers is more fun and easier. The humor is fun. The research system and edicts work well.

I played the tutorial and a quick sandbox game up through the Cold War era on medium difficulty settings. I had no problems with managing happiness, rebels didn’t appear out of the blue, teamsters didn’t get stuck in the docks, my military performed decently, etc. So it seems like the game-breaking bugs have been fixed (at least for Mac).

Minor complaints:
I went onto multiplayer, but no one else was there. Granted, this was at 3 am CST. :p

I miss being able to zoom down to street level and “walk” around my city.

I hate the way the grid overlay looks. It was perfect in T4. Now all the lines of the grid are thick and they glow, making it difficult to see the ground for good placement.
Looking forward to more updates for more polish. And once all the planned DLC comes out in a bundle, then I'll buy 'em.

reviewText:
While I found Tropico 4 the pinnacle of the series, I enjoyed Tropico 5 as another aspect to the game play that has made the series a darling.  Tropico 5’s timing seems slower paced than 4, but the consistent humor and different ways to build your nation is never repetitive.

The only thing I wished was better was the DLC package.  The DLCs are more add-ons rather than enhancements to the game.  For example, the Waterborne expansion allows me to utilize the ocean, but it’s an “okay” feature that doesn’t enhance the game.

Regardless, I’m a sucker for these games and I keep buying the DLCs in hopes that they’ll make a Tropico 6.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I enjoyed it quite a bit. It's a bit different than CIties skylines but I would say that for me it has atleast the same entertainment value if not better. Tropico 5 was definitely better than EA's simcity.
I must add that Tropico 5 is more difficult, atleast I found myself struggling with economy on my first two runs. This is because you rarely receive constant income like in other city building games, but instead you receive money when trade ships show up and buy your resources, and the income you get from a single ship is very irregular. For example one day you might receive 1k for selling bananas and weeks or months later when next ship arrives 10k for jewelry. And meanwhile you are constantly losing money to upkeep your production facilities.

Tropico 5 is quite solid actually, no bugs or anything that I've experienced. Only thing I was a bit annoyed about was that everytime autosave happened my game went to a loading screen and after that for some reason wanted to change my dynastys name, so I had to press cancel and second loading screen followed. But that can be avoided by reducing or disabling autosaves in options. Loading screens were also fairly short so I wasn't too bothered really.

It should be noted that I haven't played tropico 4. and many reviewers seem to say that it's better, so check that out before you buy and make your own conclusions.
It is quite common that Tropico 5 can be bought at discount, especially outside steam, but I can recommend it for full price as well if you like building games like I do.

reviewText:
I give Tropico 5 4.5 pairs of fancy El Presidente Brand Sunglasses out of 5. The other one got broke when El Presidente single handedly broke the noses of the Premier of the USSR and President of the USA with a swing of his beard.

Seriously, this game gets a 4.5 out of 5. Another of the great series of city-building dictator sims that made me fall in love with city-building sims again in the first place and have a personality that makes it so few people can turn away after beginning to play with them, it delivers much of what it promises, but there's tarantulas in those crates of bananas.

The first and foremost is that the voice acting has degraded, and things are less funny, than its predecessor Tropico 4. The storyline shares some mirrors to that game, ultimately, but is enjoyable despite this fact. The addition of tech research and a static continual build of your islands throughout the campaign (Which is something I greatly greatly missed in the Tropico 4 game, wishing it existed) provides a cohesive story and more believability, while keeping things humorous. Add in options like crafting your nation's constitution and it has plenty of playability, eve if your fun per minute might be lessened and ther's less commentary about your actions.

Sandbox mode remains solid, especially with the addition of a random generator for islands.

The multiplayer is a GREAT GREAT GREAT addition to the game, but that crate of bananas has a tarantula in it, too. What is that, you say? There is absolutely no save mode at all in it. So if you and your friends play 2 hours playing a multiplayer game? YOu'd better finish it because you won't be able to come back to it, you either have to devote a large chunk of time to it or play on small maps, in the end.

Finally, there are plenty of bugs and glitches, even now, including things like the menu stuttering (at least 30 people including myself had this problem, which was because an intromovie playing in the background had horrible frame rate issues) but there are easy enough fixes of these until official fixes from Kalypso come forward.

Over all? The game is a solid addition to the genre and the Tropico family. IT could have sailed higher, and it might still with DLC, but it's already far more enjoyable and far more playable for computers with lesser capabilities than its competitors in the city building genre, especially with very real trade, invasion, and competitive options in the multiplayer making an already deep game deeper.

reviewText:
Buy this game.

Every Tropico released since 3 has felt like a refinement since, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. This series has always been right where it needs to be in terms of gameplay, humor and style; it's just been a matter of perfecting it. While Tropico 5 brings the series closer than ever to perfection in an absolutely beautiful iteration of the series, it's had to take some things that fans love away in the process. But I trust Kalypso to continue to refine the game in later updates and expansions. I'd wholly recommend this game to fans and newcomes alike. Viva El Presidente.

Pros:

- Graphic updates bring you a gorgeous, sun soaked Carribean.
- Difficult. In previous Tropicos I never had an issue getting elected with the majority of the vote. Now I'm constantly on the offensive trying to figure out what needs fixing.
- Fantastic little details crammed into every corner.
- A new sense of depth to the gameplay, new strategies to be brought out, and new ways to plan your regime.
- More of the fantastic humor that's always made the series a joy to play.
- New trade and political options.

Cons:

- Faction advisors gone, no more Sunny or Ms Pineapple to update you on the latest situation.
- Difficult UI, a bit of a hassle trying to sift through all the citizens to uncover the root of a problem.
- Buildings could have used more variety and height as in previous iterations. While the graphic updates are charming, there could have been more options.
- Seriously. I miss Sunny and Penultimo's banter.

reviewText:
A singleplayer game worth your money.

Tropico 5 is a fair game for a fair price, an enjoyable Dictator simulator that while borrows many visual assets from previous games, has gameplay rebuilt from ground up. As a player who never touched campaign mode, the focus on a deep and richer sandbox mode is exactly what I wanted. Here are some ups and downs from my experience.

-DON'T BUY FOR MULTIPLAYER
Anyone buying Tropico 5 for multiplayer should definitely wait a long time, its a half-baked feature that may very well need an entire expansion (or two) to get right.

-ALMANAC
The new Almanac technically has most of the information you could get from 4, but its not very intuitive.  It takes a long itme to figure out where the important info is scurried away. Sometimes you need to scroll down, sometimes its behind an inconspicious word button. You have to explore every nook and cranny to find what you need.

+DYNASTY
The Dynasty mechanic was kind of a letdown. Its an upgrade from T4, where each skill doesn't go into a massive pool, but is tied to a specific character (who can potentially die in certain circumstances.)

+ERAS AND MISSION STRUCTURE
The Era system is the real game changer. If you've seen TotalBuscuit's T5 preview, you'll know the game has a very rigid, formulaic mission structure at the start, the Colonial Era. This is the most defining and brilliant of changes made to the Tropico series.

These Colonial missions are guide you to very specific objectives, ignoring these usually  results in a premature ending. This is done to prevent you from falling into a routine which in prior games, would kill the fun of these games after awhile. These mission chains will seem binding, that you HAVE to do exactly what these missions tell you or fail. However, as your understanding of the game mechanics come together, you can figure out how much breathing space you have to fulfill the missions while building the Tropico you have in mind.

+-COMBAT
Combat is all about expectations. Its no RTS. Its a little hands off, but for me personally its hard to react to changing circumstances. Your firepower comes only from three sources: guard towers, soldiers and tanks. If all of these sources of attack power are gone, you're effectively done.

The most depth I've found with the system is grouping Guard Towers, so that the tankiness of the towers are complemented by consistent firepower which can kill enemy units and actually turn battles around. There should be ways to react to a bad situation, by cutting deals or accepting demands.

reviewText:
Tropical Simcity basically. Build your city, research tech, grow your economy. I really like it though and would highly recommend it to anyone that likes city builders.

Pros:
The graphics are beautiful
The music is great
Lots of quests
Easy to learn
Not so subtle humor laced throught
Long and challenging Main Campaign

Cons:
Military combat is all AI (your units too)
Economy seems broken at times, either too hard or too easy to exploit
Low replayability (same quests over and over, you can plan ahead once you know what to expect)
DLC is expensive and adds relatively little each (usually 1 building, 1 mini campaign with that map also avaialbe in sandbox mode)
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Now THIS is a fun game. In my opinion, this simply is the best city builder out there. Why is that? Mostly because of the style. It feels great to be El Presidente of your own little Carribean island. Your entire island looks exactly like you would expect from a Latino-American country. Yes, in the beginning that does look quite a bit like shacks, but if you do well that will change soon enough.
And then there's the fact that you are El Presidente: this means that you can do whatever you want, provided you keep the people under control by either being popular or repressing them. The latter is my personal favorite.
But El Presidente does not rule alone. He also has a number of trustworthy advisors to help him out and keep him busy. And your number one advisor is the one and only, brilliant Penultimo!
Also, there are multiple ways to build up your island: you could build farms everywhere, industrialize or be the dream island of every tourist. Though I've got to be honest: this can get a little bit dull in your 50th game.
Up until now, this might have seemed alright but not hugely convincing. So let me tell you what is.
It is: the humour. This game is absolutely hilarious and happens quite often that I find myself laughing at yet another brilliant remark by Penultimo, though he is not your only source of fun.
So if you want to rule your own little banana-republic and laugh a lot doing so, this game is a must.

reviewText:
I bought this game, in the hope to find a good city building game, which I'm sure it was, however despite this: I found that the game would not function properly as far as the game would not go in full screen correctly, the taskbar would still be on the screen, whilst the game running in full screen mode so some of the screen would be unaccessable, meaning windows would still be running in the background thus affecting frame rates and how the game runs etc. I run a 1920x1080p monitor, a common resolution yet I got this problem; I tried to fix this by trouble shooting however the fixes did not work such as ALT+ENTER etc. I attempted a reinstall many times however the problem persisted. Luckily, I got the game for £12 on sale, so not as much money was wasted, however a game that has been out for almost a year and is pumping out DLC already, shouldn't have any issue along these lines under any circumstances. Despite this, I was very lucky because steam offered me a refund due to its issue. On another related topic: I would, from the gameplay I've seen, heard from friends and the brief while I played, I would reccomend this game for gameplay however, if you have a 1920x1080p monitor, I would say it's not worth the risk, especially at £30.

As advice to people who may have purchased this game and experience this issue or any game affecting issue significant enough for the game to not be playable, it is against UK law(only applicable if you bought and use this game in the UK), and you are entitled for a refund, however luck and good tech support is required, which I was fortunate enough to have.

Thank you for reading, for the developers on the other hand,

Please fix your games and don't let this happen again.

reviewText:
One does not settle for silver after being used to gold.

Yeah, it's Tropico allright...not. They tried to re-invent the wheel and came up with a square. It's a bit dumbed down and usable elements from the previous games were left out. Also it would seem that the studio got into taste of dlc industry with million billion different dlcs.

Also I can't help but to wonder if they had some legal problems with the used soundtracks on tropico 3 and 4. I enjoyed the vocal music on the previous games. As far as I remember in tropico 5 there is just one soundtrack with voice and that is lyricless. Or maybe it costs more to produce music like that.

The humour is of the same brand as so far. But It's tired wannabe funny, whereas tropico 3 and 4 had genuinely fun moments.

In essence there is nothing wrong with the game mechanics. But the previous installments put the bar too high for tropico 5  and they failed to meet the high standards. However it is for that I am still giving this game thumbs up. There is nothing wrong in the game, but it is NOT it's predecessors.

reviewText:
A singleplayer game worth your money.

Tropico 5 is a fair game for a fair price, an enjoyable Dictator simulator that while borrows many visual assets from previous games, has gameplay rebuilt from ground up. As a player who never touched campaign mode, the focus on a deep and richer sandbox mode is exactly what I wanted. Here are some ups and downs from my experience.

-DON'T BUY FOR MULTIPLAYER
Anyone buying Tropico 5 for multiplayer should definitely wait a long time, its a half-baked feature that may very well need an entire expansion (or two) to get right.

-ALMANAC
The new Almanac technically has most of the information you could get from 4, but its not very intuitive.  It takes a long itme to figure out where the important info is scurried away. Sometimes you need to scroll down, sometimes its behind an inconspicious word button. You have to explore every nook and cranny to find what you need.

+DYNASTY
The Dynasty mechanic was kind of a letdown. Its an upgrade from T4, where each skill doesn't go into a massive pool, but is tied to a specific character (who can potentially die in certain circumstances.)

+ERAS AND MISSION STRUCTURE
The Era system is the real game changer. If you've seen TotalBuscuit's T5 preview, you'll know the game has a very rigid, formulaic mission structure at the start, the Colonial Era. This is the most defining and brilliant of changes made to the Tropico series.

These Colonial missions are guide you to very specific objectives, ignoring these usually  results in a premature ending. This is done to prevent you from falling into a routine which in prior games, would kill the fun of these games after awhile. These mission chains will seem binding, that you HAVE to do exactly what these missions tell you or fail. However, as your understanding of the game mechanics come together, you can figure out how much breathing space you have to fulfill the missions while building the Tropico you have in mind.

+-COMBAT
Combat is all about expectations. Its no RTS. Its a little hands off, but for me personally its hard to react to changing circumstances. Your firepower comes only from three sources: guard towers, soldiers and tanks. If all of these sources of attack power are gone, you're effectively done.

The most depth I've found with the system is grouping Guard Towers, so that the tankiness of the towers are complemented by consistent firepower which can kill enemy units and actually turn battles around. There should be ways to react to a bad situation, by cutting deals or accepting demands.

reviewText:
Tropical Simcity basically. Build your city, research tech, grow your economy. I really like it though and would highly recommend it to anyone that likes city builders.

reviewText:
If you love City Building Games then I highly and most certainly recommend this game for sure. It is by far the most interesting and tedious city builder there is to date which covers a lot of ground to keep you busy and reeled in for hours on end.

There are only two major complaints I still have about this game - read why below.

1 - The Multiplayer was horrible at first and because of that the game got a really bad wrap from the get go so players stopped playing it online due to the issues it originally had. On a positive note most of those problems were fixed and it does work very well online now. However, due to that bad start it may be hard to play it online unless you go to the community or get a friend to join you.

2 - One of my biggest problems that I have always had with this game with each of it's following game sequences is that the buildings are way too repetitive as in all of the building types are the exact same. So once you get further into the game you'll notice that you have lots of areas with houses and buildings but they all look exactly alike with absolutely no variance whatsoever. I have repeatedly complained to them about this in every series and nothing has been done and I doubt now that it will ever change either unless a ton of people start to do the same. One thing though that does make it a little better is the different building types and the added buildings from the dlc but still if you have a bunch of houses and similar buildings you will notice that and it may become an annoyance. If you can look past that then you'll enjoy it! On top of that the Eras also do help aid with that in changing the look of several types of buildings after upgrades have occurred from advancing in time but many do not such as housing unfortunately.

Anyhow though, aside from those two issues it is still an epic game and I definitely think it's worth the price in full but if you'd rather wait for a sale then I would certainly recommend grabbing it for sure to say the least!

reviewText:
I've only played Tropico 4 and 5 and since most people have been commenting and reviewing on the differences between the two of them, I figure I'm qualified to review this accurately.

I highly enjoy Tropico 5. I find it very addicting as I'm a complex strategy player at heart and enjoy the extra content, options, and challenge it provides. I think the dynasty mechanic is pretty interesting, it helps you overall in game though it does suck you can't control it a little more, specifically the first names and skill trait your heir gets.

You definitely have to use your head! This is a simulation of you being a dictator after all! ANY decision you make will typically either affect you positively or negatively. How extreme depends on previous decisions you've made like who your allies are or will be and whether or not you've taken precautions to keep social unrest down. It's a lot more scale tipping than Tropico 4 and you have to have a short learning curve to enjoy this game for what it is. It's highly political and invasion is more likely from people you ♥♥♥♥ off than Tropico 4.

Overall I think it's a more realistic rendition of a dicatorship simulation. Even at Occassional" freaking random disasters

I do recommend this game!

Likes
- More challenging overall
- Nicer Graphics
- Dynasty Members Mechanic
- In Depth Import/Export Trade Mechanic
- Politics Game
- Love having building managers to increase overall production/job/building function!

Differences | Dislikes
- *BIG* Less humorous than previous Tropcios IMO. They have jokes but it's like "Ha. Ha." More than hilarous imo.
- Wish I could name and pick the trait (other than the 3 provided) for my heir
- Would like more outfits than currently provided for avatars (Might be future DLC)
- Wish I could purchase/attract more trade ships other than building a dock per trade ship ratio.
- While I like the Eras mechanic
column19:
find it a little hindering BUT NOT IMPOSSIBLE for things like tourism or imprisoning/arresting etc not able to be done earlier in the game.
- There is less of a subtle teaching mechanism in Tropico 5 than 4. You pretty much trial and error play blindly until you find yourself out of a job and have to restart the game with what you've learned. I can handle it personally but it might be a turn off for other players who need a bit more guidance in a game. (Took me a while to figure out how trade works and that I could send squads to unveil the island. No instructions on that.)

Tips
- Save Regularly. It does autosave but since crazy ♥♥♥♥ happens in short amounts of time
column20:

- Check the trade routes before you designate farms/ranches/mines. You can profit more with something in demand.

reviewText:
The game has amazing music and humorous dialogue. It provides a good challenge while simultaneously offering a relaxed and even casual play time. The new Waterborne campaign is fun and worth the money. Multiplayer is fun but few people seem to take advantage of it.  The Tropico line of games continues to impress and is a fan favorite. The company would not hurt from giving attention to a few minor details like ensuring the correct accent is given to the voices in the game (Carribbean Spanish accent versus Spain or Mexico Spanish) and other little details.

I feel like the game could do a better job with tutorials by offering advanced tutorials that show players the ins and outs of economy at a detailed level to include how to maximize trade and edicts. Also, constitutional choices and how they affect factions and political standing.. Explanations on why my island might have 100 job openings and 100 unemployed even when I am making them pay for their own healthcare and food would be nice.

The game has much more potential especially if they focus on multiplayer. Allow each player to have their own islands and conduct trade with each other, setting their own prices, etc. Marine and Air warfare. Corporate espionage and sabotage. Paying pirates to invade th other players. Joint ventures.

reviewText: I've only played Tropico 3 on the Xbox (briefly) and have extensively played Tropico 4, but Tropico 5 takes the cake for me. The graphics are greatly improved and the campaign feels much more interesting to me than the past games - you have two islands to jump between, with their own achievements and research and everything so it doesn't really feel stale. That being said, there are still problems from Tropico 4 that didn't get fixed in Tropico 5, including the ever-aggravating road system...but it's something you adjust to, in my experience.\n\nOverall, good game. I recommend it, and if you can get it on sale, I recommend that more. 4/5

Think i would like to check out its predecesors now, and maybe fork out for the expansion.

A cautionary tale at the very least.
